name: John Marugg
skills: ['Technology Transfer', 'Biotechnology', 'Commercialization', 'R&D', 'Lifesciences', 'Polymers', 'Pharmaceutical Industry', 'Chemistry', 'New Business Development', 'Biopharmaceuticals', 'Medical Devices', 'Innovation Management', 'Strategy', 'Start-ups', 'Organic Chemistry', 'Business Development', 'Biochemistry', 'Patents', 'Formulation', 'Drug Delivery']
summary:
Dr. John Marugg
Is an experienced and seasoned business creator and leader in the medical and pharmaceutical field. He has build several businesses in medical devices ; medical innovations ; drug discovery and validation ; biotechnology and small molecule API. He is now member of the Brightlands Maastricht Health Campus and responsible for business development and business creation. He is now co-founder and CEO at Corporis Medical a medtech company with HQ at the Brightlands Maastricht Health Campus.

 Previous roles include Senior Director for the Drug Delivery Center of Excellence at DSM Biomedical where he was responsible for leading the Drug Delivery team and managing the strategy its business and technology development . He combined this role with a role in the management team of DSM Biomedical.

John has worked in the Pharmaceutical and Medtech industries in various senior Sales and Marketing positions. He served as Business director for Medical Coatings, a high growth business in Medical which under his leadership, was initiated and build into a successful business . Prior to that John was Director of Marketing and Sales/VP of Business Development for DSM Biologics, where he was responsible for all business development sales and distribution activities, strategic planning and process implementation in Biologics. Prior to his role as Sales/VP of Business Development, John was the Director of Business Strategy and Acquisitions at DSM Fine Chemicals, where he was responsible for strategic planning and M&A for various business units. 

In his 20+ years with the company, he has negotiated various multi-year development, technology license and manufacturing deals with large pharmaceutical, Medical and biotech companies, divested businesses and assets, set up of world wide distribution networks and dealth with suppliers and customers with high-risk exposures. 
John holds two patents and has over 13 published editorial pieces in top scientific journals. John holds a PhD, Masterâ€™s degree in Organic Chemistry and Biochemistry, and a Bachelorâ€™s degree in Chemistry from the University of Leiden, the Netherlands.

summary:
First year PhD Candidate at the AUMC Graduate School with a project focusing on designing and assessing companion biofluid biomarkers for targeted therapeutics in neuroinflammation. The project will be within the Neurochemistry laboratory which focuses on researching biomarkers for Neurodegenerative diseases, such as Alzheimer's disease and Multiple Sclerosis.

I am a graduate from the MSc Neurosciences at the VU Amsterdam, with a minor in Science Consultancy from the University of Amsterdam, and a BSc in Biochemistry from the University of Southampton. My past research has focused on Alzheimer's disease (AD), with one half-year internship at the pathology department of the AMC and a second 5-month internship focusing on bioinformatic analysis of AD with functional characterisation in cortical organoids.

field of studies 2: HBO-A Clinical Chemistry /HBO-B  Biochemistry /HLO Molecular Biology
skills: ['Molecular Biology', 'Molecular & Cellular Biology', 'cell Biology', 'Biochemistry', 'Radiation Safety', 'Molecular Imaging', 'Reverse Transcription Polymerase Chain Reaction (RT-PCR)', 'PCR Primer Design', 'Clinical Chemistry', 'Sequence Analysis', 'Parasitology', 'Microbiology', 'Life Sciences']
summary:
At the Department of Parasitology of Leiden University, I introduced Molecular Biological Techniques from the mid-80s to the early 90's, and established the molecular biology lab that laid the foundation for Molecular Biological Research on rodent malaria parasites. This made it possible for other reputable researchers to be attracted, then the fundamental research on malaria parasites gained more depth and strengthened partnerships with national and international malaria researchers.
Moreover, I contributed to refine the Leiden Rodent Malaria research model, supported the development of transfection of malaria parasites and set up imaging techniques for malaria research. Besides running the Molecular Biology lab my expertise is mainly used for genetic modification , analysis of malaria parasites, supporting researchers and giving guidance to students. The resulting mutant and transgenic malaria parasites are subjected to studies in mosquitoes with additionally genetic and immunological studies to ultimately obtain parasites for applicable "live malaria" vaccines.

summary:
In the continuity of my Master's thesis, in July 2018 I started a Ph.D in the CTR group (Complex Tissue Regeneration) at MERLN under the supervision of Lorenzo Moroni. I am actually working on the development of an innovative vascular system allowing the transition from the macro- to the micro-scale. This subject is part of the B2B (Breast to Bone) European project.

I obtained a Bachelor's degree in "Biomedical Sciences" in 2015, at the Faculty of Fundamental and Biomedical Sciences for Health in the University Paris Descartes, France. During my Bachelorâ€™s degree, I specialized in immunology and metabolic chemistry. Then, I graduate my Master's Degree "Health Engineering and Biomaterials" in 2017, at GalilÃ©e Institute in the University Paris Nord. 

I performed my final-year internship in the ART unit (Accelerator of Technological Research) of the BioTis laboratory, INSERM U1026, Bordeaux, France. My topic was the development of a perfusable, cellularized and hierarchized vascular system designed by 3D bio-printing using micro-extrusion and inkjet technologies.

I have a good knowledge in biology, immunology and biochemistry as well as in biomaterials and nanomaterials field for medical applications, especially medical devices.

summary:
Iâ€™m the founder of not one, but two small-but-successful digital marketing agencies: Maison Leads & Doing Digital.

We work with unique types of clients. Doing Digital is focused on the online appearance of your business. We do coaching, social media marketing, (video) content creation, and everything else creative. Basically, we can be your online creative director. Here we focus on up-and-coming businesses that are as ambitious as we are, and determined to scale their brand as quickly as possible.

With Maison Leads we offer one service to one niche: Paid Advertisement for Real Estate and Property Businesses. That's it. Being this specific helped us to develop our skills and become very specialized in this field. We learned that speaking to all is speaking to none, and that is exactly what we implement for our clients. The main takeaway is: weâ€™re advertisers, focusing on one thing and doing it well.

Personally, Iâ€™m quite fond of good food and restaurants with an amazing atmosphere. My current favorite restaurant is TABU, in downtown Dubai. Their Dynamite Shrimps are insane. 

If youâ€™d like to apply to work with me or one of my agencies (or chat food and restaurants), feel free to drop me a message.

name: Ruben Elands
skills: ['Marketing', 'Communication skills', 'Sales', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Microsoft Excel', 'SPSS', 'Speaking in public', 'Trading Cryptocurrency', 'Teamwork', 'International Relations', 'Research', 'Strategy', 'Politics']
summary:
The year 2022 was a challenging, but mostly a remarkable year. In August I obtained my Master degree in Political Science at the Radboud University Nijmegen. While studying, I also started my first real (temporary) job at the State Supervision of Mines (SodM). This regulating organisation is part of the Ministry of Economic Affairs and Climate. Combining both studying and working was challenging, but I successfully acquired my Master. I specialised in International Relations and in my thesis I examined the theories neorealism and neoliberal institutionalism to explain the increased focus of the Chinese Belt and Road Initiative on Africa. In this thesis many of my interests converged. 

In 2018, during my bachelor Business Administration, I did my exchange at the Beijing University of Technology. I enjoyed my time there and kept my interest. I tried to continue my efforts in mandarin and so far I secured my A2/HSK 2 language certificate at the Radboud University. To stay informed about China I read a lot and I voluntary teach Dutch to some Chinese speakers. This already for four years.

My interest in Africa grew during my graduation internship in South-Africa. I did my internship at Origin Wine and wrote an export strategy for the Chinese wine market. After coming back, my interest never faded. Therefore I am very proud to contribute to De Africast (podcast) with its goal to dispel all the misconceptions that many have on the African Continent. The podcast, wherefore I am the editor in chief, is an initiative by NIGIZ, where I am in the board. 

After my internship in South-Africa I joined Krijger & Partners Krijger as Government Relations Advisor with focus on the geopolitical developments around China. I was supporting and organising several China events and provided support to businesses and organisations. I was also working part-time at China Circle and joined the board of the Young China Circle after the Ministry of Foreign Affairs presented the Dutch China â€œStrategyâ€.

Because I my warm feelings for entrepreneurship, together with a friend with which I studied in China, we founded East Commerce Group. We did this in partnership with a merchant in Hong Kong shipping company and imported different kind of products. This was a very educational period, but I decided that I wanted to continue studying. After studying in China and South-Africa, my work at Krijger & Partners and my ephemeral time in business, I decided to change course and enrolled for the pre-master in political science at the Radboud University. The rest is history.

I work as a researcher, data steward and researcher at the Methods & Statistics unit of the faculty of Pedagogical and Educational Sciences.

My current roles:

â— I am a lecturer in the course Inferential Statistics, which is offered to both premaster students (Feb + March) and bachelor students (April + May), respectively.

â— As a data steward, I am responsible for the storage of research data (adherence to FAIR principles) and ensuring GDPR (EU privacy law) compliance in scientific research conducted at the institute.

â— My research is focused on two key projects:

- Learning Analytics â€“ I develop learning analytics to gain insights into study progress. As an example, I try to understand the learning trajectory in nongraded, formative quizzes through process variables such as duration, login time, and quiz grades.

- Psychometrics â€“ I use simulated data to better understand how statistical models answer research questions relevant to psychological science. As an example, I simulate experience sampling method data that fits analyses with Multilevel Regression Model and with Multilevel Latent Markov Models to uncover when both analyses can best be applied.


Ambition:

I am currently seeking a PhD position starting this summer, and would be delighted to hear from anyone who feels my expertise and research interests would be a good fit for their team. Please feel free to reach out to me at your convenience.

Analytical techniques I have used and/or studied:

- Dynamic Network Models
- Discrete Latent Variable Models (e.g., Latent Class Analysis, Latent Markov Models)

I started my higher education by doing a Bachelorâ€™s in Chemistry with a specialization in Forensic Chemistry. During this study several techniques (e.g. LC, GC, UV-VIS and AAS) were discussed and practiced. Further, my Bachelorâ€™s covered also parts of Physics, Biology and Criminology. I did three projects: one major project (Comparing fluorescent dyes for quantitative DNA analysis) and two internships. During my first internship I carried out a literature study into postmortem biochemical markers and a project into body cooling & temperature measurements (published in Int J Legal Med 130(2)). My second internship was a research into decomposition of human tissue in strong inorganic acidic and basic solutions (BASc. thesis).

After finishing my Bachelorâ€™s, I started a Masterâ€™s in Chemistry with a specialization in Analytical Science. During this Masterâ€™s I obtained knowledge on physical-chemical properties of molecules, separation, detection and data analysis (MATLAB). My Master's thesis focused on detection of veterinary drugs in canine ear tissue using liquid-liquid extraction and GC-MS (Shimadzu GCMS QP2010 Ultra).

I did my PhD in the School of Pharmacy of the University of Nottingham focussing on the use of liquid extraction surface analysis-tandem mass spectrometry (LESA-MS/MS) for high throughput quantitative analysis of proteins adsorbed onto polymer microarrays in relation to cell response. Here, I worked with different Orbitrap mass spectrometers (Exactive, Q Exactive plus, Q Exactive HF).

After, I joined the Life Science Trace Gas Facility, Radboud University Nijmegen as a postdoctoral researcher to work in the NUTRISHIELD project which involves the analysis of volatile organic molecules in relation to dietary quality of children.

Currently, I hold a researcher position in the Life Science Trace Detection Laboratory (www.ru.nl/tdlab) where I am responsible for the mass spectrometry division of our lab.

name: Julija VaitonytÄ—

summary:
I come from a tiny Baltic country, Lithuania, but my insatiable curiosity brought me to different places, including, Spain, China, the UK and the Netherlands. The Netherlands is the country in which I have done most of my education and research by now. In 2023 I will defend my dissertation dedicated to the study of Intelligent Virtual Agents (IVAs). IVAs are artificial entities capable of behaving socially and engaging in natural conversations with humans. Relying on a mixture of methods, I studied how people perceive the appearance and behavior of virtual entities at both behavior and the brain level. While conducting research on IVAs, I also have had a unique opportunity to be part of the team contributing to the development of a virtual entity on the ViBE (Virtual Humans in the Brabant Economy) project, where I have learned about 3D scanning, language models, and behavior generation for IVAs.

In addition to my doctoral work, I am an active science communicator. I love writing and science, and I find interest in numerous topics, ranging from biology and the brain to technology. Blogging has been the way to first teach myself about the world, and to hopefully inspire a constant thirst for knowledge in others. My texts have been published in various outlets in English, Lithuanian, and Dutch, such as Donders Wonders, de Gelderlander.nl, Radboud Recharge, Mokslo sriuba, and LOGIN.LT. 

I have a love for science that includes event organization. In 2021 my fellow PhD Researcher and I started the AI Forward Forum initiative, which provides a platform for researchers, practitioners, and artists to discuss artificial intelligence (AI). By doing so, we aim to connect different ideas from the sciences, humanities, and arts in the context of AI. To date, we have hosted many leading speakers from across Europe and the USA. You can find information about upcoming events at aiforwardforum.com.

name: Mariska Kret
skills: ['Cognitive Neuroscience', 'Statistics', 'fMRI', 'Psychology', 'Experimental Design', 'SPSS', 'Scientific Writing', 'Research', 'Science', 'Neuroscience', 'Neuroimaging', 'Research Design', 'Quantitative Research', 'Social Sciences', 'R']
summary:
Summary of research
My PhD focused on the perception of emotional body language and innovated the field of affective neuroscience that was characterized by an almost exclusive focus on facial expressions. I showed that the brain processes body movements similarly as facial expressions but initiate clearer action patterns. I argued that body language is evolutionary seen much older than facial expressions and inspired by Darwins work on emotions and by contemporary primatologists, I experimentally tested this statement in a group of chimpanzees at the Kyoto University Primate Research Institute. With use of the emotional dot probe paradigm presented on a touch-screen, I showed that chimpanzees process chimpanzee body language similarly as humans do. Thanks to the interactions with these beautiful animals, I developed an interest in the use of eye-signals. Humans are the only species on earth with much visible eye-white that evolved for communicative purposes. Despite this difference with the chimpanzee, I have shown that humans, as well as chimpanzees synchronize their pupil-size with their own species. 
My Postdoctoral appointment at the University of Amsterdam enables me to connect these earlier insights to social psychological work on social decision making and intergroup differences. It resulted in (co) authored publications on the substantial role of oxytocin in social approach and withdrawal tendencies. My VENI project (starting in January 2015) builds on these three lines of work â€“ emotion recognition and mimicry, pupil-synchronization, and oxytocin-motivated social decision making.

www.mariskakret.com

summary:
I am Emeritus Professor of Functional Linguistics at VU University Amsterdam, now mainly working as a Consultant in Languages and Linguistics, with over 40 years of experience behind me. My skills and expertise are primarily in European languages, with a specialization in English linguistics; I am fluent in several European languages. I take a functionalist approach to language analysis; that is, I am convinced that the structure of languages is adapted to their primary purpose, communication between human beings. I am editor of the world's major journal in functional linguistics, Functions of Language.

I have been associated with three research groups: SCIMITAR, at Santiago de Compostela, Spain; EMO-FUNDETT, at UNED, Spain; and CELGA-ILTEC, at Coimbra, Portugal. I am experienced in research assessment and have worked for several years as an expert -- and in 2012 as lead expert -- for EACEA, an agency of the European Commission.

Specialties: Functional linguistics
Postgraduate training and supervision
Curriculum development

summary:
Arie Verhagen has been the chair of Dutch Linguistics at Leiden University from December 1998 until July 2016. He is now Professor of Language, Culture, and Cognition at the same university. Since April 2013, he is also Academic Director of the Humanities Lab, the Honours College Programme of the Faculty of Humanities of Leiden University (see http://www.humanitieslab.nl).

Arie's research and teaching focus on the dynamics of the connections (in discourse, ontogeny, and phylogeny) between the use of language in communication and grammatical systems, employing cognitive linguistics and (cultural) evolutionary theory as broad frameworks. See www.arieverhagen.nl for more information and publications.

name: Yuri Engelhardt
position 1: Assistant Professor of Data Visualization and Information Graphics
skills: ['Data Visualization', 'Information Visualization', 'Interaction Design', 'Information Design', 'Research', 'Teaching', 'Human Computer Interaction', 'Information Graphics', 'Lecturing', 'User Experience', 'Information Architecture', 'Social Media', 'Graphic Design', 'New Media', 'University Teaching', 'Graphics', 'Theory', 'Graphs', 'Public Speaking', 'Digital Media']
summary:
I have been fascinated by and thinking about information visualization for more than 30 years.  I attended my first Information Design conference in 1992 (London), my first CHI (Computer-Human Interaction) conference in 1993 (Amsterdam), and the very first InfoVis (Information Visualization) conference in 1995 (Atlanta).  My academic work has been quoted by Colin Ware, Stuart Card, Jock Mackinlay, Ben Shneiderman and other key authors in the field of information visualization. Over the years I have learned a lot from my personal face-to-face discussions with very inspiring scholars and mentors such as Jacques Bertin, Hans Rosling, Donald Norman, Nigel Holmes, Richard Saul Wurman, Barbara Tversky, Clive Richards, Alberto Cairo, and many others.  

I am passionate about the use of data visualization, information graphics and visual analytics in the context of social and environmental causes â€“ especially in areas such as the climate emergency, education, health, sustainability, environmental protection, human rights, transparency, data journalism, and capacity building in developing countries and emerging economies.

I am teaching and supervising students in computer science, graphic design, journalism, media studies, creative technology, cartography and other disciplines, supporting them in a broad range of interesting adventures in data visualization.

I love exploring how the visual exploration and understanding of information can be improved, and trying to understand the 'design space' and the 'building blocks' of data visualizations and the ways in which these can be combined to construct useful, attractive visualizations.

name: Lourens De Vries
skills: ['Lecturing', 'Theory', 'Science', 'Academic Writing', 'Translation', 'Religion', 'University Teaching', 'Teaching', 'Linguistics', 'Research', 'Literature', 'Higher Education', 'History', 'Intercultural Communication', 'Social Sciences', 'Editing']
summary:
The research of the General Linguistics group focuses on the inductive and database-driven typology of language systems, with an emphasis on the empirical cycle where general linguistic typology and descriptive linguistics of Austronesian and Melanesian languages feed and modify each other. 

Since the strength of linguistic typology depends to a large extent on the quality of the grammars which feed the databases, the group has a special interest in all aspects of fieldwork methods and descriptive linguistics from the use of software tools (PRAAT, Language Explorer 8) to standards for data collection and processing, linguistic argumentation and ethical fieldwork. 

And since Austronesian and Melanesian linguistics have a long and strong tradition of cross-disciplinary research focusing on themes shared with anthropologists, archeologists, geneticists, historians and biologists, we also have a special interest in linguistic relationships (areal, genealogical, typological, statistic) as instruments within cross-disciplinary contexts for the study of human prehistory and population movements. Our focus here is on the prehistory and migration paths of the ancestors of Austronesian, Melanesian and Papuan speech communities.

summary: Men beweert dat de persoonlijkheid van jonge kinderen een indicator is voor hun latere karakter. Zo stond ik als 4-jarige kleuter boos voor mijn kleuterjuf: â€œIk kan al lezen, ik kan al schrijven. Waarom mag ik dan niet naar groep 3?â€. Deze bevlogenheid en drang tot zelfontwikkeling zit er zeventien jaar later nog steeds in. Wanneer een taak mij echt aanspreekt, ga ik hiermee het liefst zo snel mogelijk aan de slag. Ik kan oneindig veel uren bezig zijn met werk waar ik enthousiast van word. Deze aviditeit in combinatie met mijn leergierigheid en empathisch vermogen zijn karaktereigenschappen die mij tot een toevoeging maken. In het dagelijks leven ben ik graag creatief bezig. Het volledig plannen van een reis of leuke activiteiten met vrienden maakt mij echt enthousiast.

name: Amber Brabander

summary: Creatief, gedreven en assertief; mijn naam is Amber Brabander, afgestudeerd redactiemedewerker, AD Crossmediale Communicatie specialist en Communicatie- en Informatiewetenschapper en op dit moment masterstudent Neerlandistiek. Als klein meisje op de basisschool daagde ik mijzelf al uit door dikke boeken te lezen die eigenlijk nog niet voor mijn leesniveau geschikt waren. Naast mijn passie voor lezen, ben ik het liefst zoveel mogelijk bezig met het vertellen van verhalen. Vanaf het moment dat ik het alfabet leerde, begon ik met schrijven. Vroeger was ik nooit zoâ€™n prater, dus drukte ik mijn gevoel uit in woorden op papier. Mijn personages bezochten de tombes van Toetanchamon, vonden hun langverloren tweelingzus en hadden af en toe lange oren en een pluizig staartje. Op twaalfjarige leeftijd heb ik mijn droom verwezenlijkt; het uitgeven van een eigen boek. Daarom kwam mijn keuze voor de mbo opleiding Redactioneel Medewerker absoluut niet uit onverwachte hoek. Na het afronden van deze onwijs leuke opleiding waarin ik ontzettend veel heb geleerd, besloot ik mijn horizon te verbreden en aan de hbo opleiding AD Crossmediale Communicatie te beginnen. Communicatie bleek mijn onontdekte passie te zijn en ik kan al mijn creativiteit kwijt in dit uitgebreide vakgebied. Na het behalen van mijn diploma, ben ik in het verlengde van mijn hbo opleiding Communicatie- en Informatiewetenschappen gaan studeren aan de Universiteit Utrecht. Na het behalen van mijn wo bachelor diploma, ben ik op dezelfde universiteit begonnen met mijn master Neerlandistiek. Ik leer iedere dag steeds meer en dat met veel plezier. Ontzettend gemotiveerd en altijd op zoek naar nieuwe uitdagingen, dat ben ik. Ik ben te nieuwsgierig om dingen niet uit te pluizen en te leergierig om lastige zaken weg te leggen. Alle kansen die ik tegenkom pak ik met beide handen aan. In de loop der tijd is er nog niets veranderd; ik ben nog steeds zo gedreven als dat kleine meisje op de basisschool.

name: Michael Glennon
skills: ['Research', 'Lesgeven', 'Management', 'Hoger onderwijs', 'Sociologie']
summary:
I work in several areas: language coaching and scientific writing support for students and professionals, teaching social theory and social scientific research methods to students in higher education, and exploring the relationship between language and society with a particular emphasis on the subject of children and linguistic diversity in European urban areas.
  
Language Coaching and Writing Support: I provide language coaching for groups and individuals seeking  improvement and greater confidence in their use of academic English. I also offer support services for professionals and students working on specific scientific writing and/or formal academic English language texts, e.g. scientific articles, dissertations, theses, lectures and presentations, reports, proposals and etcetera. Additionally, I offer translation of reports, white papers or other documents for education and research.
 
E-learning, Sociology, and Higher Education: I possess more than twelve years of experience in online instruction. This experience includes teaching sociology at a college level to a wide variety of students for universities and colleges in the American Midwest, and the development of original online courses covering a wide range of topics relevant to the social sciences. Presently my course design efforts focus on enhancing the accessibility of course content. Making sure content is accessible not only to people with different learning styles, but also to people with impairments.   

Researcher and Social Scientist: I have specialized education and experience in the use of ethnographic and discourse analytic research methods. In the past I applied these skills to a social scientific research  on the subject of community based services for people with intellectual disabilities, and to the cultural politics of autism and autistic rights. Presently I am designing a framework for a comparative analysis of experiences raising multilingual children in the Netherlands and Germany.

summary:
Student Communication Science with a Political Science background. In 2017 I started the Bachelor's programme Political Science at Radboud University. I'm interested in recent political-societal issues and international relations. I've lived in the United States (Memphis, TN) for six months to study American politics and Strategic Media in an international environment.

After receiving my Bachelor's degree, I changed course and started with the Communication Science program. Since 2018, I work at the Marketing & Communications department of Radboud University. I started as study advisor for prospective students and I'm now coordinating the Bachelor's Open Days. I also assist our CRM team with their projects. My work inspired me to dive deeper into the communications field, specifically into marketing communication, social media, and content marketing.

Born and raised in the 'Achterhoek' (Eastern part of The Netherlands) but since 2017 I've found my place in the city of Nijmegen. I like to take on new challenges, present my ideas, and critically review the cases I come across.

name: Marina Tulin
skills: ['Academic Writing', 'Quantitative Research', 'R', 'Gephi', 'Prezi', 'Social Network Analysis', 'Structural Equation Modeling', 'Meta-analysis', 'Project Planning', 'Cross-cultural Teams', 'Constructive Feedback', 'Public Speaking', 'University Teaching', 'Project Management', 'Stata', 'Python']
summary:
I am an Assistant Professor of Education, Citizenship and Democracy in a Digital World at the Amsterdam School of Communication Research (ASCoR) at the University of Amsterdam (UvA). My research interests include false information, fact-checking, media literacy as well as public trust in institutions like journalism and science.

Previously I worked as a Postdoctoral Researcher at the University of Amsterdam and the European Digital Media Observatory. In this position I contributed to systematically studying the problem of misinformation and the potential of fact-checking in the Dutch and Belgian context.

Prior to this (2020-2022), I worked as a Postdoctoral Researcher in the Department of Media and Communication at Erasmus University Rotterdam, and the coordination manager of the Horizon 2020 project 'Trustworthy, Reliable, and Engaging Social Science Communication Approaches' (TRESCA).

I hold a PhD in Sociology (2020) from the University of Amsterdam. My PhD research aimed at better understanding social capital and segregation in networks. 

I am skilled in quantitative research, social network analysis, public speaking, and project management. I've been involved in a variety of data collection projects involving field experiments, lab experiments, collecting hormonal samples, scraping network data, mining text data, and conducting semi-structured interviews.

summary: As an Assistent Professor of the School of Business and Economics of the VU, I conduct research in the fields of Social Entrepreneurship, Sustainable Entrepreneurship, Circular Entrepreneurship and Hybrid Organizing. I am greatly inspired by the Entrepreneurship as Practice lens and therefore I mostly conduct ethnographic fieldwork. My current research focuses on how circular entrepreneurs develop their resilience in times of crisis and I examine the role of social interactions among entrepreneurs and between entrepreneurs and mentors in this process. Additionally, I teach courses on Organization Theory and Sustainable Entrepreneurship and I supervise theses on the topic of Entrepreneurship.

summary: I am a behavioural scientist who is curious about the dynamic interplay between humans and technology in the field of (health)care. I am interested in the underlying behavioural mechanisms that drive technology acceptance. My ambition is to create more understanding about users of technology and explore creative methods to involve them in the design process. With my research, I strive to contribute to the sustainable implementation of technologies that empower citizens and (health)care professionals.

name: Winona Kamphausen
field of studies 2: Political science and social and economic history
skills: ['Social Media Communications', 'Writing', 'Attention to Detail', 'Communication', 'Public Relations', 'Mentoring', 'International Relations', 'Model United Nations', 'Event Management', 'Fundraising', 'Logistics Management', 'Affiliate Marketing', 'Content Marketing', 'Market Analysis', 'Moderating', 'Constructive Feedback', 'Event Organizing', 'Text Editing', 'Proofreading', 'Legal Advice']
summary:
I am a highly motivated and ambitious Research Master in European Studies at Maastricht University, passionate about history, the European Union, international relations, and political decision-making. My master's thesis will explore the role of women in the European Parliament during the European Economic Community, focusing on "The â€˜missingâ€™ women of European Integration".

As part of my two-year degree, I am currently interning with Dr. Aline Sierp (Maastricht University) on a research paper about norm-building in memory studies. I am also a research intern with the Contested Histories Project by Euroclio, where I write reports on controversial monuments and street names. My experience with these internships is helping me to develop my analytical and research skills.

In addition to my studies, I am the head of the Marketing department of the European Careers Association Maastricht (ECA). As the marketing team leader, I work closely with my colleagues to implement our marketing strategy and promote ECA. I am also a German teacher at Belingual Maastricht, which allows me to share my knowledge and expertise with others.

During my Bachelor's degree in political science and social and economic history, I participated in Erasmus and spent time at Tartu University, Estonia. This experience sparked my passion for history and the European idea. I was also an active member of Model United Nations, participating as an organizer, delegate, or chair in more than 10 conferences during my Bachelor's. In my last year, I discovered a passion for Marketing, which I was able to explore through an internship with the Unicorn Factory. name: Claes de Vreese
position 1: University Professor University of Amsterdam | Director DDC
position 2: Member Royal Dutch Academy of Arts and Sciences KNAW
skills: ['Social Sciences', 'Research', 'Lecturing', 'Political Science', 'Quantitative Research', 'Journalism', 'Politics']
summary:
Claes H. de Vreese is University Professor of Artificial Intelligence and Society (2021-), with a special focus on media and democracy at the University of Amsterdam. He holds the Chair in political communication at the Amsterdam School of Communication Research ASCoR. He (co-)directs the UvA Platform Information, Communication and the Data Society (ICDS), including the Research Priority Areas Communication, Personalised Communication, and Human(e) AI. He is the founding Director of the Center for Politics and Communication (www.polcomm.org). He is member of the ICA Executive Committee and served as President 2020-21.

He is also Scientific Director of the Digital Democracy Center at the University of Southern Denmark. 

His research interests include the role of automation, algorithms, and artificial intelligence in democratic processes. This includes microtargeting, news recommenders, social media platforms, disinformation, comparative journalism research, the effects of news, public opinion and European integration. His research has been funded by several science foundation grants, including an ERC grant, VENI and VICI grants from the Dutch Science Foundation, as well as grants from various EU research programs. He has received awards for research from the International Communication Association, the Danish Science Foundation, and the Holberg Foundation. He is recipient of the Swanson Career Achievement Award (ICA, 2018), the NeFCA Career Award (2019), and he is an elected Fellow of the Royal Dutch Academy of Sciences, the International Communication Association, and the Royal Holland Society of Sciences.

From 2004-2006 and 2010-2021 he chaired the Program Group Political Communication & Journalism in The Amsterdam School of Communication Research ASCoR. Between 2005 and 2013 he was the Director of ASCoR and NeSCoR. From 2013-2016 he served as Adjunct Dean of the Faculty of Social Sciences (FMG) at UvA. De Vreese is a former member (2012-2020) and the Chair (2017-2020) of the KNAW Social Science Council (SWR). From 2017-2020 he chaired the national SSH Council.

He has published 200+ articles in international peer-reviewed journals.

He has been visiting scholar at Harvard University, Netherlands Institute of Advances Studies, University of Zurich, and SDU. He served as Editor in Chief of Political Communication (2014-2020) and the International Journal of Public Opinion Research IJPOR, and he serves on the Editorial Board of several ISI ranked journals. He has lectured in a dozen of countries and frequently appears in (inter)national news media.

summary:
Research
As a cultural psychologist as well as a scholar of religion, my academic interests are scattered across both the social sciences and the humanities. They include religious and aesthetic experiences, mysticism, meaning-making, creativity, rituality and magical thinking, and also cultural transmission, evolutionary psychology, ecological approaches (embodied embedded cognition), identity construction, consciousness, religious self-legitimation, and human atmospheres.

I also have an interest in psychoanalysis, philosophy of science, theory and method. My research skills range from quantitative methods in general to qualitative onesâ€”such as interviewing, participatory observation, and content analysisâ€”in particular. I am currently involved in two research projects: one on religious self-legitimation (together with Leonard van â€˜t Hul), and one on human atmospheres.

Teaching
I have extensive experience in teaching, developing teaching material, and coordinating courses in both the social sciences and the humanities (most notably cultural psychology, psychology of religion and religious studies). I have taught both undergraduate and graduate students at university and at the first, second, and last year at college (â€˜hogeschoolâ€™) level. I have taught regular students as well as adult learners and have done so in Dutch and English.

The teaching formats of the courses I participated in range from individual supervision (more than 120 undergraduate and graduate theses) to practicals, seminars (of 10-30 students), and lectures (up to 120 students). Apart from the development of course material, I have constructed and validated exams, edited readers, wrote syllabi and for several years coordinated two courses of some 450 students each. As part of these activities, I have supervised teaching assistants and junior lecturers and offered them didactic training, intervision sessions, and personal guidance in the form of class visitations and one-on-one coaching.

Style
Co-workers and students describe me as (see testimonials):
â€¢	enthusiastic and energetic

â€¢	approachable and reliable
â€¢	loyal and critical

name: Andrew S. Hoffman
position 2: Research Associate, iHub - Interdisciplinary Hub for Digitalization & Society
skills: ['Qualitative Research', 'Data Analysis', 'Lecturing', 'Statistics', 'Research Design', 'Editing', 'Grant Writing', 'Database Administration']
summary:
Hi! I'm Andrew and I am a Data Steward in the Faculty of Social and Behavioral Sciences at Leiden University in the Netherlands.

In this capacity, I spend much of my time liaising with researchers and support staff in Cultural Anthropology & Development Sociology (CAOS) and the Centre for Science & Technology Studies (CWTS) to address any and all Research Data Management needs â€“ from assisting in drafting Data Management Plans, to choosing long-term data storage/archiving, assembling Publication Packages, or any number of other facets of RDM that social science researchers encounter in their work.

Additionally, I also work closely with my team of Privacy, Security, and Data Management experts in our faculty, as well as with colleagues at Leiden's Center for Digital Scholarship, to develop resources and tooling that will assist researchers and fellow RDM professionals alike in navigating the rapidly shifting and sometimes daunting landscape of new policies, protocols, and ever more forms to fill out.
 
In my previous lives, I've been a Research Data Coordinator in academic cancer medicine (NYC, US); completed a doctoral degree in sociology with a concentration in social studies of medicine (McGill University, CA); and worked as a (sometimes-competitive) oyster shucker in the great state of Maine. I've also held a couple of postdoctoral fellowships (University of Washington, USA & Radboud University, NL), where I was studying and working alongside sociotechnical infrastructure development projects, predominantly in the field of translational science & medicine. 

It is here that I gained a keen appreciation for the promises, difficulties, and overall hard work it takes to implement concepts like Open Science and the FAIR Data Principles in everyday research practices â€“ both in the fields that I have studied, but also in my own work as an ethnographer of knowledge infrastructures. And it was an interest in confronting these challenges as an RDM practitioner, where I could help researchers and policymakers make sense of each others' distinct epistemologies (or whatever you call it), that led me to my current work as a Data Steward.

Beyond these pursuits, I love reading novels on my morning commute to work, watching tennis in the evenings, accumulating way more LPs than I'll ever have the time to listen carefully to, and seeking out lighthouses in distant corners of the world with the partner of my dreams and the kid for whom we share responsibility.

summary: I am a Postdoc at the Chair of Systems Design at ETH Zurich, where I study societal transitions and communication networks. I am particular interested in how European society in the 16th century changed as a result of the Reformation, a social movement that overthrew the Catholic Church. For example, I analyse how scholars specialised in their communication roles and why territories adopted Protestantism. A central aim of my research is to understand the driving factors of transitions, accounting for interdependencies and heterogeneities in complex social systems. This is achieved by merging analytical tools and concepts from various disciplines such as Social Network Analysis, Event History Models, Potential Outcome Model of causality, and conventional regressions.

Eslam is a Postdoctoral Researcher in Digital Heritage at Maastricht University (Netherlands). He is currently working on the collaborative research project Terra Mosana, which aims to investigate, digitize, and communicate the shared history of the Euregio Meuse-Rhine (EMR). He is also affiliated to the Department of Architecture at Assiut University (Egypt). His main research interests are related to digital heritage, interaction design, emerging technologies (e.g. AR, VR, and tangible interaction), human-computer interaction; focusing on designing, implementing and evaluating interactive systems that help users to gain insights and knowledge, in particular the communication of heritage information and visitorsâ€™ engagement in museums and beyond.
He holds a five-year bachelorâ€™s degree in Architectural Engineering from Assiut University (Egypt). In 2011, he obtained a joint Master Degree in Management of Cultural Heritage and Landscapes as an Erasmus Mundus scholarship (UniversitÃ© Jean Monnet, France - UniversitÃ  Federico II, Italy â€“ UniversitÃ¤t Stuttgart, Germany). In June 2019, he received his PhD degree from KU Leuven (Belgium) in Architecture, where he introduced the approach of â€œPhygital Heritageâ€, which entails how heritage information can be disclosed via simultaneous and integrated physical and digital means, as a potential medium for engaging and meaningful communication of heritage to the broader public.
He has published more than 20 peer-refereed papers; most of them are in the field of digital applications on cultural heritage, including both international journal articles and conference papers.

name: Achilleas Psyllidis
position 1: Assistant Professor of Location Intelligence & Spatial Analysis | Director, Urban Analytics Lab
skills: ['Spatial Analysis', 'Location analysis', 'Urban science', 'Machine Learning', 'Data Science', 'Data Mining', 'Location Intelligence', 'Urban Planning', 'Research', 'Design Research', 'Geographic Information Systems (GIS)', 'GIS', 'R', 'Urban Informatics', 'Geocomputation', 'Urban Computing', 'Geovisualization', 'Artificial Neural Networks', 'Smart Cities', 'Ontology Modeling']
summary:
I am an Assistant Professor of Location Intelligence and Spatial Analysis at Delft University of Technology (TU Delft). I lead the Urban Analytics Lab at the Faculty of Industrial Design Engineering. I direct the Social Urban Data Lab at the Amsterdam Institute for Advanced Metropolitan Solutions as a Research Fellow. In addition, I am affiliated with the Leiden-Delft-Erasmus Centre for BOLD Cities.

My research spans the fields of city design, urban mobility, and spatial data science. I focus on measuring and evaluating urban design qualities that contribute to more walkable, sustainable, healthy, and welcoming cities for all. I am convinced that in order for cities to achieve their public health and sustainability goals, quantifiable targets and standards must be developed and consistently measured. As a result, I develop evidence-based measurable indicators, which are frequently co-created with stakeholders, to help cities transition to a healthier, fairer, and more sustainable future for all citizens. I incorporate these metrics into software tools to assist designers, planners, and policy-makers in assessing pedestrian accessibility, walkability, safety, playability, and other perceived qualities of the physical environment. To identify, represent, and prioritize the factors that ensure our urban spaces are accessible, welcoming, and healthy, I bring together approaches from urban science, public health, and systems thinking with cutting-edge mobility research and spatial data science methods. I am involved in several national, European, and international research projects about cities, mobility, environmental exposures, health, and well-being.

Before joining the IDE faculty, I was a postdoctoral researcher within the Web Information Systems (WIS) group, at the Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Mathematics, and Computer Science (EEMCS), TU Delft, between 2016 and 2019. I hold a PhD in Spatial Data Science from TU Delft (2016), as a scholar of the Onassis Foundation, the European Union Social Fund (ESF), the Greek State Scholarships Foundation, the Foundation for  Education and European Culture, and the A.G. Leventis Foundation. I have also served as a research affiliate of the Joint Research Center for Spatial Information (Wuhan University & TU Delft), and of the Joint Research Center for Urban Systems and Environment (South China University of Technology & TU Delft).

skills: ['Computational Social Science', 'Python (Programming Language)', 'Machine Learning', 'Research', 'Data Science', 'digital infrastructure', 'Social Media', 'Marketing Communications', 'Dutch', 'Public Relations', 'Microsoft Office', 'Microsoft Word', 'Photoshop', 'English', 'Teamwork', 'PowerPoint', 'Microsoft Excel', 'Theatre', 'Facebook', 'Social Media Marketing']
summary:
I am an Assistant Professor of Corporate Communication at the Department of Communication Science at the University of Amsterdam.

Research

My research examines bias in digital media and methods using computational techniques and experiments. I analyze depictions of social groups and their impact on prejudice and discrimination. I also investigate how digital technologies influence biases in hiring and recruitment, focusing on implicit biases in algorithms and unconscious biases of recruiters. I am particularly interested in the consequences of algorithmic profiling for vulnerable job seekers, such as older individuals, in the digital job market. Additionally, I am exploring the content, causes, and effects of bias in computational tools, supported by an NWO Open Competition grant, specifically examining the degree to which annotation bias contributes to bias in machine learning models and its downstream implications for classification.

Impact: Digital Infrastructure and Data Science

As a lead member of various infrastructure and data science initiatives, my primary goal is to accelerate computational and data science research for SSH-researchers. I am responsible for coordinating the PDI-SSH funded project Twi-XL, which creates an infrastructure for cross-media research, and co-leading the ODISSEI-funded Media and Content Analysis Lab (MCAL), which integrates content analytical tools and communication science data into the broader SSH-infrastructure landscape. Additionally, I am the communication science representative of the Social and Behavioral Science Data Science Center of the University of Amsterdam. 

Teaching and supervision

I specialize in teaching and supervising computational social science techniques. I am passionate about sharing knowledge on big data and digital methods through seminars and courses for both undergraduate and graduate students. As a co-supervisor of several PhD candidates, I have experience guiding research projects where computational methods play a central role.

Affiliations

I am affiliated with ASCoR, and part of the Program Group Corporate Communication. In addition, I am a member of Computational Communication Science Amsterdam, and the EU-funded OPTED project. Finally, I act as a supervisor and research member of the ERC project NEWSFLOWS.

Since many years I have been the technical director of the Digital Methods Initiatives (DMI), one of Europeâ€™s leading schools for internet studies. In that capacity I developed dozens of tools to gather, analyze and visualize web data. 

I enjoy team work, which is part and parcel of my academic career, and my participation in numerous multidisciplinary collaborative projects and publications testifies to my being a reliable team worker. I have worked as a researcher and programmer in numerous international and interdisciplinary research projects, including the investigation of political search at Yahoo! research Barcelona, the study of internet censorship with citizenlab.org, and mapping controversies in Bruno Latour's projects on Mapping Controversies in Science and Politics (MACOSPOL) and Electronic Maps to Assist Public Science (EMAPS). 

My organizational experience and skills come to fore in multiple areas: I am coordinator of the MA Journalism and Media, the technical director of the Digital Methods Initiative, I have trained and supervised the departmentâ€™s programmers, I have coordinated various B.A. and M.A. courses, I supervised M.A. theses, and I have been the chair of the Board of Studies of the Media Studies M.A.s for the past few years. summary:
I am a Core Lecturer in Computational Social Sciences at the University of Amsterdam and an Assistant Professor at the School of Business Administration at the American University Kyiv.

My PhD dissertation â€œGenres, webs of fields, and institutional change: The development of dance in the US, UK, and the Netherlands, 1985-2005â€ at the Sociology Department of the University of Amsterdam is about to be submitted. The study is supervised by Alex van Venrooij (University of Amsterdam) and Giselinde Kuipers (KU Leuven).

I completed my master in Cultural Sociology (Cum Laude, University of Amsterdam) with a thesis titled â€œThe culinary order: sustainable consumer identities and new organizational forms on the alternative market for foods.â€

The two studies are characterized by rather different substantive domains (dance vs sustainable food), yet they also share a connection due to their focus on how the interplay between change-seeking movements and established actors shapes processes of innovation. My research uses computational and qualitative/historical methods. It draws, predominantly, on the literature from cultural sociology, organization and social movement studies.

You can find more information - including my blog posts on Python programming - on my personal website: https://www.renswilderom.nl/

summary:
I like games, especially those connecting people to places through pervasive technologies.

I conduct Research through Design on playfulness, urban spaces, interactive narrative, and design fiction.
I'm inspired by Humanistic HCI, and I draw on Interaction Criticism, Ethnography, Critical Design, and Narrative Semiotics.

I work at the Eindhoven University of Technology where I am Assistant Professor in the department of Industrial Design
and research group in Systemic Change.

I was previously employed at the Amsterdam University of Applied Sciences (NL), Indiana University (USA),
University of Bologna (Italy), and University of Modena and Reggio Emilia (Italy).

I was Head of Program of the M.Sc. Digital Design (AUAS), leading up to its successful reaccreditation in 2022.
I have taught design ethics, design futures, research methods, games and interaction criticism, and persuasive design.

I was in the steering committee of the ICIDS conference series.
I was involved in co-organizing and chairing Trust in Play - European School of Urban Game Design, CHI Play 2017,
Games for Cities and Design & the City.

I co-edited the volumes A Lab of Labs: Methods and Approaches for a Human-Centered Design,
and Interactive Digital Narrative: History, Theory and Practice,
as well as the journal issue G|A|M|E 5(1) Games on Games. Game design as critical reflexive practice.

As a practitioner, I create geolocalized narratives, playful interactions and "games for cities".
I am interested in design fiction, speculative design and critical design.

And I wish for more free time to travel the world.

Annalisa Pelizza  is Professor of Science and Technology Studies (STS) at the University of Bologna, where she holds the Chair in Sociology of Communication Processes. Before joining Bologna, she was Associate Professor at the University of Twente, department of Science, Technology and Policy Studies (STePS).
Her research focuses on STS-informed methodologies to study fleeting online sociability, and on governance by data infrastructures shaping modern institutions. With her work, Annalisa brings tools proper to STS analyses to investigate and expand information systems studies and political sociology. This combination is made possible by her former experience working with governmental agencies and engineering companies, developing large-scale IT infrastructures.
Annalisa Pelizza was the recipient of several European Commission scientific grants and currently leads the â€œProcessing Citizenshipâ€ (http://processingcitizenship.eu) research group, funded by the European Research Council. The team investigates transnational data infrastructures for migration management as activities of European governance transformation. She has held visiting professorships at the Center for Technology in Society at the Munich Technical University (2016), the Institute for Advanced Studies in Paris (2017), the University of Twente (2019-2022).

field of studies 1: Agent based modeling of Urban Health Interventions
skills: ['Agent-based Modeling', 'GIS', 'Sustainable Cities', 'Data Analysis', 'Research', 'Economics', 'Analytical Skills', 'R', 'SQL', 'Python (Programming Language)', 'Teamwork', 'Problem Solving', 'Englisch', 'Spanish', 'Spatial Data', 'Urban Geography', 'Predictive Modeling', 'Data Analytics', 'Web Scraping', 'Network Science']
summary:
I am deeply fascinated by cities, their complexity and the diversity of their components, but also their potential in addressing the most pressing social, ecological and economic challenges of our time. Passionate for sustainable transitions, I took it upon me to understand as good as possible the interactions between the built and physical environment, sociotechnical systems and the behavior of people and resources, which as a whole cause the emergence of more or less desirable outcomes. I believe that urban and regional sciences and development is an exciting field to work in, considering all the new technological possibilities and the creativity that can be used to find solutions to highly salient problems.

I am currently doing my PhD in Agent-based Modeling of Urban Health Interventions to prevent cardio-metabolic pulmonary diseases at the Institute for Risk Assessment Sciences and the Department of Geosciences at Utrecht University as well as UMC Utrecht. For that, I am integrating GIS and ABM simulation modeling to understand exposure dynamics in cities (air pollution, noise, physical exercise, active transport) and how urban interventions can help addressing them. Moreover, I am attempting to quantify all social costs and benefits of the analysed intervention scenarios.

For the long run, I decided for myself that I want to work in two fields simultaneously: Research and Development. Interfering in such a complex system as a city, I think one cannot go without the other. 

 I have gathered substantial experience and skills to conduct robust science
- I completing my Research Master of Science in Urban and Economic Geography with summa cum laude (GPA 8.75) at Utrecht University
- I was a research assistant at the Center for Science and Technology Studies in Leiden
- I was a visiting student and research Assistant at the MIT Sustainable Urbanization Lab, Cambridge, USA
- I am capable of doing: Regression modelling, Agent-based Modeling, Network Science, advanced GIS, Cluster Analysis, simple Neural Nets and more
- Experience organizing physical and online conferences and events

Next I also collected experience in urban development
- internship within a city development department in MÃ¶nchengladbach, Germany
- intership in a regional development NGO in Batticaloa, Sri Lanka
- started a software development project for urban resource and favor matching to help communities deal with the new challenges of Covid-19 (we participated in the Covid19 Global Hack and EUvsVirus Hackathon)

Currently, I am an assistant professor at the Department of Advanced Computing Sciences and at Maastricht Law+Tech Lab (Faculty of Law), at Maastricht University (UM) in the Netherlands.

My current work/research lies in the area of Social Machine Learning and includes computational social media modeling, dialogue systems (with applications in customer service & psychology), pattern discovery/network modeling from multimodal data sources and topic detection and tracking from large document collections. I like building responsible and interpretable machine learning models for domains like psychology, arts, law, etc.

I am contributing to the research themes of Machine Learning and Human Behaviour Understanding, Affective and Visual Computing and since September 2019 I joined part-time the Maastricht Law and Tech Lab where we launched inter-alia the Computational Social Media research group.

summary:
I am a senior data scientist, focusing on enterprise-level customer analytics and VoC (voice of consumer). I have an academic background in computer science, a Ph.D. in distributed optimization, and a postdoc in NLP. 

Currently, I am acting as the tech lead for PMI's VoC project, where in addition to developing, monitoring, and maintaining models; I help with creating solution/data architectures, and data pipelines that can handle large quantities of textual data. Basically, I'm working on orchestrated pipelines that can take text data from 20+ languages, detect their relevancy to PMI, tag the brand/products they are talking about, finds out their sentiment toward a pre-defined set of topics, and present them as actionable insights to the business.

I am skilled in training/fine-tuning/deploying NLP models (such as GPT-3, RoBerta, T5), MLOps aspects of such systems (such as orchestration via Airflow, model registry via MLFlow, container management, and orchestration via Kubernetes, and ...), and cloud computing (such as AWS toolings and Sagemaker for model serving). Additionally, during my academic career, I have developed expertise in multi-agent systems, distributed optimization, and multi-objective socio-technical system design.

Food for thought: how to detect different analogies and euphemisms people use to refer to certain brands/products/topics in their native language?!

Currently, I work as a researcher at the Amsterdam Police Department.

In 2007, I completed the master Forensic Criminology at Leiden University. After my graduation, I worked as a lecturer and researcher in Criminology at Leiden University and VU Amsterdam. In 2011, I started a large scale PhD project on residential burglary at Ghent University. I succesfully defended my doctoral dissertation in June 2016. Afterwards, I worked as an Assistant Professor of Criminology at Leiden University. My academic research focussed on repeat and near repeat burglary patterns, and the effect of corporate characteristics on the chance of regulatory violations of these companies. 

Keywords: burglary, corporate crime, white collar crime, quantitative analysis, observational research

name: Isabella Regan
skills: ['Projectplanning', 'Lesgeven', 'Analytisch denkvermogen', 'Onderzoek', 'Criminology', 'International criminal law', 'Research', 'Qualitative research', 'Quantitative research', 'SPSS', 'Microsoft Excel', 'Microsoft Word', 'Academic writing', 'Human rights', 'Organisational skills']
summary:
Colleagues and friends describe me as a criminologist with a broad interest and an open mind. I think out of the box and try to bring together concepts from different disciplines, to creatively enhance scientific thinking about legal practice - notably international criminal investigations.

I'm specialized in international crimes, conflict and gross human rights violations. Besides knowledge on criminology specifically and social science generally, I have knowledge on a range of international law: criminal, humanitarian, human rights and refugee law.

At the moment I am a PhD researcher in criminology at Erasmus (Graduate) School of Law. The title of my research project is "New power dynamics? Public and private power (im)balances within online open-source investigations of international crimes".

After graduating as a master of science in international crimes and criminology (cum laude), I worked for an international human rights ngo for a number of years. During this time I was lucky to work for and with incredible human rights organizations and activists and enhance their knowledge on monitoring and reporting (severe) human rights violations in Africa and the Middle East. I was fascinated and interested by how private actors - such as human rights activists - contribute to international criminal justice. As a result, after a few years working in practice I returned to academia with the aim of bringing together both worlds: criminology and human rights investigative practice. Specifically, I wanted to delve into the dynamics between official public (criminal) investigations and the private practice of human rights investigations. 

After a few years of teaching criminology and law students and spending any free time I had reading into the practice of online public and private investigations, I wrote a research proposal and applied to Erasmus School of Law for a fully funded PhD position in criminology. A position I am very happy to have been offered. Through qualitative research methods I intend to add to the theoretical and empirical body of knowledge on public-private power dynamics in (international) criminal investigations, specifically focusing on those actors involved in online open-source investigations.

name: Julienne Weegels
skills: ['Human Rights Research', 'University Teaching', 'Lecturing', 'Workshops', 'Latin American Studies', 'Violence', 'Prisons', 'Ethnography', 'Gender Studies', 'Anthropology', 'Creative Writing', 'Qualitative Research']
summary:
I'm assistant professor of Latin American Studies at the University of Amsterdam - Centre for Latin American Research and Documentation (CEDLA). Trained as an anthropologist, I'm specialized in ethnographic research on violence, (dis)order, (prison) governance and state-(un)making, particularly in Nicaragua. Currently I also work on these topics in the city of Amsterdam, as PI on the research project "Het Ongelijkheidsbeginsel" (the principle of inequality), which takes a holistic approach to understand the ways in which urban inequalities (spatial, socio-economic and racial/ethnic) are mitigated and/or reproduced through criminal justice interventions.

At the same time, I continue to research practices of (para-)policing, imprisonment, state crime and organized crime in Nicaragua. In relation to the 2018 protests and their aftermath, I work with (former) political prisoners and their family members, Nicaraguan exiles and refugees, and human rights activists in doing so. I am currently working on two book projects. The first is a volume I'm editing with Hanneke Stuit and Jennifer Turner, titled "Carceral Worlds", which explores the expansion of carcerality in our globalized present and how this may be unsettled. The second is a book manuscript based on my doctoral thesis, which was awarded a cum laude distinction. This thesis "Performing Prison: Power, Agency and Co-Governance in Nicaraguan Prisons" was based on 31 months of multi-sited ethnographic research conducted between 2009 and 2016 with long and short-sentenced (former) prisoners of three Nicaraguan prison facilities.

In general, I am much interested in the day-to-day workings of prison life and the (development) of carceral/penal states, policing and other forms of non-state/extralegal surveillance and governance, always with a focus on questions of power and legitimacy, violence, gender and the body. To this end, I participate actively in a number of interdisciplinary networks on confinement and prisons research, including the Global Prisons Research Network (as a co-organizer), the EASA Anthropology of Confinement Network (former co-convener), and the Americas Prisons Research Network/Red Penitenciaria de las Americas (founding member). 

I'm always open to collaborations and exchanging ideas. If you'd like to get in touch, please feel free to write me at j.h.j.weegels@uva.nl. Thank you!

Besides research skills such as ethnographic fieldwork, interviewing and analysing data â€“ my education and international experience have trained me in intercultural communication. summary:
I am an anthropologist, Latin Americanist and victimologist. My research explores whether and, if so, how legal, quasi-legal and non-legal transitional justice procedures affect the daily lives of those who experienced political violence, gross human rights violations and mass victimisation.
I have a keen interest in the themes of:	
- Transitional justice, particularly the right to and politics of reparations
- Participation, citizenship, state-survivors relations in post-conflict societies
- Victim labelling and victim identities
- Human rights, international justice
- Alternative justice epistemologies and social comparison
- Ethnography, phenomenological research, participatory research, visual methods, mixed-methods
- Peru, Colombia, Cyprus, Guatemala, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Guinea-Conakry, Northern-Iraq
- Latin America

summary:
ENGLISH BELOW

â€œGrote dingen gebeuren niet alleen door een impuls, maar als een opeenvolging van kleine dingen die met elkaar verbonden zijn.â€ (van Gogh)

Ik geloof in de alledaagse kleine acties die voor de grootste impact kunnen zorgen. Dit kan een gesprek zijn met een vreemde in het park. Dit kan een autorit van een uur zijn met een persoon die je pas net hebt ontmoet. Het is een rimpel effect dat klein begint maar daarna zich alleen zal verspreiden als je het laat zijn. 

Als project manager verzorg ik de dagelijkse operaties zodat een mooi resultaat geleverd wordt. Ik ga door bij tegenslagen en vraag altijd â€œHoe kan dit anders?â€. Ik combineer een goede dosis van analytisch denken en het onderscheid maken tussen het essentiÃ«le en niet-essentiÃ«le. Verder neem ik altijd mijn enthousiasme en humor mee naar werk. 

Project management | Communicatief | Verbindend  | Creatief | Leergierig

---

"Great thing are done by a series of small things brought together" (van Gogh) 

I believe that it is small mundane actions that can generate the biggest impact. This can be a conversation with a stranger in the park. This can be a one hour car drive with a person you just met. It is a ripple effect that starts very small but can only expand if you let it be. 

As a project manager I take care of the daily operations to create a great result. When facing challenges I ask myself the question â€œHow can I do this differently?â€ I combine a good dose of analytical thinking and discerning between the essential and non-essential. Further, I always make sure I bring in enthusiasm and humor to work.

Project management | Communicative | Connecting | Creative | Studious

skills: ['Project Management', 'Diversity & Inclusion', 'Human Rights', 'Communication', 'Diversity Program Development', 'Organization Skills', 'Public Policy', 'Teamwork', 'Critical Thinking', 'Business Development', 'Problem Solving', 'Leadership', 'Management', 'Cultural Diversity', 'Social Media Marketing', 'Interpersonal Skills', 'Time Management', 'Digital Marketing', 'Management Consulting', 'Curriculum Development']
summary:
Patrick van der Pas (He/They) is a well-experienced policy expert and project manager at PTRCKVDPS (+10y) in the fields of Diversity, Equity, Inclusion & Accessibility, and business development. As a change agent, they love solving complex social and cultural policy challenges and projects. 

By exploring the dynamics of contexts from a multidisciplinary perspective, Patrick van der Pas contributed to the success of different projects and companies in a wide range of industries. In 2021, Patrick was a Senior Human Rights Officer for Copenhagen 2021 where they organized a 3-day hybrid Human Rights Conference with multiple plenary sessions and over 60 break-out sessions for over 2.500 participants, which brought together activists, corporates, governmental officials such as ministers and heads of states, and over 300 organizations globally. Fun fact: Patrick wrote the keynote speech for Her Royal Highness The Crown Princess of Denmark at the opening ceremony. Additionally, Patrick contributed to the realization of other events in the name of WorldPride and EuroGames such as the Interparliamentary Plenary Assembly and the Embassy Engagement Program.

Other highlights of Patrick's career are their role as Project Manager for Global Pride 2020, bringing together hundreds of organizations, artists, and state officials from all 7 continents, reaching an audience of 57 million people worldwide. He created strong collaborations with big tech companies such as YouTube, Google, Sony Music, and Meta, to utilize their platforms for the event. Furthermore, Patrick prepared a policy analysis and lobby strategy report for WordProof, analyzing European privacy laws and policies on blockchain technology, and how these technologies can contribute to advancing internet safety. 

Starting at the most practical-oriented education level Patrick van der Pas worked his way to a double masterâ€™s degree in Public Policy and Human Development from Maastricht University and United Nations University. Another highlight of Patrickâ€™s educational trajectory is the fact that they successfully completed three minors during their bachelor's in Cultural Anthropology and Development Sociology; 1) Global Health, Care & Society, 2) Gender & Sexuality, and 3) Governance and Policy. 

In their pastime, Patrick van der Pas is a Human Rights advocate working in the international civic & social organization industry for over ten years and always looking for new challenges.

summary:
Mijn naam is Janneke Vos-Arwert. 
Ik houd van politiek, heb jarenlang op de achtergrond van de politiek gewerkt, en vind het boeiend om te zien hoe partijen vanuit diverse achtergronden samen aan de slag gaan om beleid te maken. Maar ook blijf ik me verdiepen in allerlei kwesties en vind het interessant wat er in een bepaalde situatie aan de hand is, hoe het ontstaan is, welke aspecten mee gewogen moeten worden, welke oplossing, strategie of beleid het beste is. Ik schrijf of adviseer daarover graag en houd oog voor mensen die ermee te maken krijgen om hen recht te doen. 

Dat vraagt nauwgezet onderzoek, ter plaatse met mensen in gesprek gaan, onderzoek in literatuur of archief, maar ook samenwerking met collega's, online of fysiek op kantoor. Daar zet ik me graag voor in.

name: Sam Branten
summary:
Gemotiveerd om de waarde van kunst en cultuur voor de maatschappij te vergroten en overtuigd van het belang van een toekomstbestendige cultuursector, help ik als adviseur bij Berenschot culturele organisaties en overheden bij beleids- en bedrijfsmatige vraagstukken.

Met een groot hart voor de podiumkunsten en affiniteit met kunst en cultuur in de breedste zin, zet ik me in voor een weerbare en wendbare cultuursector, die toegankelijk is voor iedereen. De publieke waarde van een levendig cultureel klimaat is onbetwistbaar, maar de cultuursector -van (mogelijk-)makers tot instellingen- is kwetsbaar. Dat heeft de coronapandemie (opnieuw) duidelijk gemaakt. Hoe kun je als overheid de culturele sector in de volle breedte helpen overleven, ondersteunen bij transities en vooruitgang en innovatie stimuleren? Welke strategie kies je als culturele organisatie in tijden van crisis?  Hoe creÃ«er je een gezonde financieringsmix? Hoe blijf je relevant en vind je aansluiting bij het bestaande Ã©n nieuwe publiek â€“ het publiek van de toekomst? Met veel energie en enthousiasme zoek ik, samen met mijn collegaâ€™s bij Berenschot, naar duurzame oplossingen voor dergelijke complexe vraagstukken.

Tijdens mijn masterstudie Kunstbeleid & Kunstbedrijf leerde ik over de rol die kunst en cultuur innemen in de samenleving en de (problematiek van de) financiering van kunst en cultuur, vanuit verschillende perspectieven: de overheid, de particuliere sector en het publiek. Door mijn eerdere werkervaring als adviseur en projectleider bij Kunstloc Brabant, weet ik goed wat er speelt in het veld. Zo verbind ik de theorie aan de praktijk. Adviseren doe ik met een kritische en pragmatische blik, met oog voor context en nuance.

Naast mijn werk bij Berenschot ben ik lid van de Raad van Toezicht van Factorium Cultuurmakers, centrum voor cultuureducatie (muziek, dans, theater), en zit ik in het bestuur van Theater De Nieuwe Vorst, beide in Tilburg.

summary:
Ik ben een ambitieuze afgestudeerde Cultuurwetenschapper, binnen de Master gespecialiseerd in openbare -en nationale bibliotheken, met de doelstelling om cultuur en kunst binnen elk mogelijk cultureel veld te blijven stimuleren en publiek bij het podium te blijven betrekken. Een tevreden publiek maakt een culturele instelling naar mijn mening sterk en nuttig. 
Mijn doel is mijn specialisatie in openbare bibliotheken en hun beleid rondom laaggeletterdheid, de komende jaren uit te breiden met kennis en inzicht in de relatie tussen de gemeente/ het sociaal domein, ProBiblio, provincie en de openbare bibliotheek. 

Zoek de beste manier om korte lijntjes te laten ontstaan tussen taalvrager en taalschool, betaal de vrijwillige Taalbaliemedewerkers die hÃ©t lijntje vormen tussen vraag en aanbod - en onderzoek kritisch hoe iedereen binnen een gemeente zich verbonden en begrepen kan voelen. Streef naar inclusiviteit en ontplooiing.

Ik houd mij als adviseur basisvaardigheden onder andere met burgerschap, gecijferdheid, Taalhuiscertificering, jongeren en (beperkte) basisvaardigheden, sociaal-juridische vaardigheden en Werk en Inkomen bezig.

summary:
Begon tijdens mijn studie pedagogiek als onderzoeker bij de Leidse universiteit en het Programmeringscollege Onderzoek Jeugd (PCOJ), tot 1993. Daarna zeven jaar in Duitsland. Bij terugkeer, 2000, start bij het NIZW: Nederlands Instituut voor Zorg en Welzijn, centrum Jeugd, later het NJI: Nederlands Jeugdinstituut. Kernbegrippen: interculturele communicatie, teamspeler, verbinding, goed kunnen inleven in de ander, overzichtelijk en volgens planning werken, zelfstandig, betrokken, kritisch denken, analyseren, reflecteren, creatief, initiatief nemen, oplossingsgericht denken, presenteren.

skills: ['Onderzoek', 'Training', 'Communicatie', 'Oplossen van problemen', 'Analytisch denkvermogen']
summary: Enthousiaste Duitse Taal en Cultuur student, die zich bezighoudt met structuur en relaties tussen talen. Met een kritische blik analyseer ik talige problemen in de Duitse taal. Zelfstandigheid en een goede planning staan daarbij hoog in het vaandel. Door intensieve interactie met Nederlandse en Duitse medestudenten, heb ik geleerd met meerdere culturen om te gaan en problemen vanuit verschillende perspectieven te bekijken. Daarnaast vind ik het belangrijk, dat iedereen zich prettig voelt bij het werk hij of zij doet. Ik ben daarom ook bereid een stap extra te zetten en mensen te helpen wanneer zij dit nodig hebben. Verder ben ik vrij conventioneel en mensgericht. Om die reden vind ik gestructureerd werk en een veilige werkomgeving erg belangrijk. Ik weet nog niet precies wat voor soort functie of type organisatie bij mij past, maar wat ik belangrijk vind zijn de volgende elementen: goede werksfeer, variatie, werk waarin ik mensen kan helpen en werk wat ik leuk vind.

summary:
I recently obtained my research master degree in Econometrics and Business Analytics at the Faculty of Economics and Business, University of Groningen. I am a Ph.D. student at the same faculty since September 2020.

My current research focuses on the economics of aging and social insurances.  In a first project, I study inequalities in health and mortality of the elderly. As an extension of this project, I currently develop a dynamic structural model to quantify the welfare implications of integrated social insurances. In another line of research, I study the importance of survivor benefits to prevent poverty after widowhood. The economics of aging is a broad concept that I explore during my Ph.D..

For further information you can visit my personal webpage: https://sites.google.com/rug.nl/jeroenvandervaart/
