summary:
I am viciously curious to find out what people (cognitively) do, far beyond what they think they do. 

â€œThe conscious brain thinks itâ€™s the Oval Office, but it is actually the Press roomâ€ 
                                                                                                                        -	Jonathan Haidt

â€œWhat gets us into trouble is not what we don't know. It's what we know for sure that just ain't so.â€
                                                                                                                        -	Mark Twain

Research
As a researcher at Maastricht University, I have found joy in balancing the challenging cord of multidisciplinary research. Functioning as behavioral economist in the Real Estate group, I currently investigate the behavioral impact of crisis on policy and performance.. I am able to do so thanks to my degrees in Psychology and Behavioral Economics as well as additional training in (Sustainable) Finance, Marketing, and Econometrics. 

Teaching
Being an adamant believer of letting nothing go to waste, I put my degree in Education to work, making sure students in my courses are motivated, knowledgeable, and eager. A low threshold for approachability and a high bar concerning expected performance characterizes my teaching style. The willing will be able. 
 
Community
Finally, I am a strong believer (and the living evidence) that research is not solely for genius people.  As such, I am the proud organizer of the SBE Science Slam, in which young aspiring researchers present their research in a fun and relaxed off-campus setting to an unknowledgeable audience.

Specialties:  Cognitive and Social Psychology, Decision Science, Human Behavior, Marketing, Consumer Psychology, Biases and Heuristics, Behavioral Economics, Education and Training, Project Management, Statistics (STATA and SPSS), Cooperation and Coordination, Creativity. 
Bonus: Mad Google Skills and Humor (debatable)

name: Mathilde Stich

summary:
My name is Mathilde Stich, and as of October 2022, I have undertaken the position of analyst at the technology-driven law firm Zeidler, joining the Counterparty Due Diligence team. 

During my MSc Political Science and Political Economy at the LSE, I have acquired invaluable knowledge in the field of political economy, both substantively and methodologically. In addition to developing crucial skills in quantitative causal inference and analysis, my courses encouraged me to engage critically with data-based work and evaluate the strengths and weaknesses of vari- ous empirical methods. Through the completion of coursework and the upcoming writing of my Masterâ€™s dissertation, I learnt to conduct research independently, acquiring practical experience in applying the scientific methods I learnt to topics that are of interest to me. Those methods include the mastery of Excel, Stata, LaTeX, and I have a strong desire to familiarise myself with other programmes, such as R. Overall, my studies provided me a new overarching perspective on the way politics shape societies, and vice versa. I am particularly interested in how electoral outcomes shape fiscal, macroeconomic, and environmental policy.

My quantitative skills were first developed in a business setting, during my BSc International Business at the University of Maastricht, in the Netherlands. My classes in finance, economics, quantitative methods and econometrics allowed me to acquire serious knowledge in mathematics and their application to real-world contexts, as well as crucial expertise in international trade and the business world. During my studies, I have also demonstrated strong organisational skills: I have completed almost an extra yearsâ€™ worth of credits through participation in my facultyâ€™s Honours Programme and my undertaking of a minor in human and legal decision-making (jointly with the faculties of law, psychology and economics). 

In addition to my skills in research and data analysis, I am a strong communicator and listener, very eager to learn and embrace new challenges. I speak English, French and German fluently and I thrive in multi-cultural settings and intellectually stimulating.

name: Yasmine Van der Straten
degree 1: Master of Philosophy - MPhil, Cum Laude
skills: ['English', 'Public Speaking', 'Economics', 'Law', 'Teaching', 'Research']
summary:
I am a PhD Candidate in Finance at the University of Amsterdam and Tinbergen Institute and a visiting PhD-scholar at De Nederlandsche Bank. My supervisors are Prof. Dr. E.C. Perotti and Prof. Dr. F. Van der Ploeg. My research is in climate finance and focuses on understanding the effects of financial frictions on effective strategies for addressing climate change.  I have two main areas of study:

In my work on climate change adaptation, I examine the relationship between financial constraints and optimal adaptation to physical climate risk at the household level.  I study the dynamic consequences on housing, income, and wealth inequality, and evaluate the design and political feasibility of policies aimed at alleviating the effects associated with financial constraints.
As financial factors shape the transition to a sustainable and low-carbon economy, I also study the interaction between financial frictions and climate transition risk at the corporate level. I examine how these frictions affect the pace of the green transition and explore the impact on the pricing and ownership dynamics of corporate bonds.

I hold an MPhil in Economics from Tinbergen Institute (with distinction), a Bachelor of Science in Economics (with highest distinction) and a Bachelor in Law from Erasmus University Rotterdam. 

Visit my personal webpage via: https://www.yasminevanderstraten.com

name: Kim Teunissen
skills: ['WordPress', 'Search Engine Optimization', 'Online marketing', 'Keyword research', 'Content Creation', 'Creative thinking and writing', 'Canva', 'EViews', 'Microsoft Office (Word, Excel, Powerpoint)', 'Microsoft Power BI', 'Google Analytics', 'Webdesign', 'Professional social media management', 'Multilingual', 'Time management ', 'Pitching', 'Sales', 'Interviewing', 'Market analysis']
summary:
My curiosity about consumer behaviour and neuropsychology, has led me to studying business psychology. I learn more every day about i.a. social and cognitive psychology, business economics, game theory, and behavioural sciences.

My main interests are neuroeconomics, investor behaviour, colour nudging, financial decision making (neurofinance), and neuromarketing. The processes in the brain during decision making fascinate me. 

In the future I would very much like to focus on choice behaviour related to marketing, in other words; neuromarketing. How can you for instance choose the right marketing techniques to influence your target group, and therewith generate the desired (buying) behaviour? Also, what happens in the consumer's brain when they see a certain advertisement, and how can this be used to improve your marketing? 

The new insights provided by the rapidly upcoming field that is neuromarketing are refreshing and could significantly boost a marketing strategy. As an open-minded person, I hope that during my MSc in Human Decision Science at Maastricht University, I will be able to extend my knowledge regarding the psychological side of everyday business!

name: Nuno Almeida Camacho
skills: ['Articulate 360', 'Product Innovation', 'Design Thinking', 'Data Mining', 'Higher Education', 'Survey Research', 'Lecturing', 'Market Analysis', 'Statistical Data Analysis', 'Qualitative Research', 'Statistical Modeling', 'University Teaching', 'Publishing', 'Mentoring', 'Academic Publishing', 'Applied Econometrics', 'Behavioral Economics', 'Marketing Research', 'Market Research', 'Marketing Strategy']
summary:
I teach marketing strategy at the Erasmus School of Economics. 

In my research I specialize on behavioral insights in the areas of innovation and marketing, i.e. the application of behavioral models and analytics to (i) understand, predict and influence customer decisions and to (ii) better understand customer behavior (customer insights). I also examine drivers and consequences of firms' strategic marketing and innovation decisions.

In my research, I often focus in life sciences industries (with a focus on patient-physician decision-making), as well as other B2B and tech-intensive industries such as automotive, telecommunications, chemicals/energy, etc. To study interesting managerial questions empirically, I typically use large-scale datasets and state-of-the-art econometrics techniques. I also design and run field and online experiments.

Over the years, I have worked on a variety of marketing strategy and innovation-related topics with firms across the globe. For instance, I coached venture teams at major multinational companies such as Alcatel-Lucent, Aliaxis, Baxter, Mahle, Merck, Michelin, SABIC, etc. I have also worked with several other large companies in executive education programs (e.g., Boehringer Ingelheim, Merck, Novartis), as well as on customer and market insights (e.g., Aliaxis, Baloise, NOS, Merck, MSD). I frequently supervise students working on applied quantitative marketing research projects at a variety of companies and industries (e.g., Ahold, BP, Coolblue, Danone, IDC, Movvo, Plus, Salsa Jeans, Shell, Sonae). 

Specialties: Customer Insights, Market & Customer Analyics, Life Sciences Marketing, Innovation, Crowdsourcing, Behavioral Economics, Marketing Strategy, Bayesian Learning.

summary:
Op dit moment schrijf ik mijn scriptie voor de studie Econometrie en Operationele Research. Begin juli verwacht ik dit af te ronden. Daarna wil ik de theorie uit de studie in de praktijk brengen, en graag meer leren op en naast de werkvloer. Om een realistisch beeld te geven van mijn capaciteiten: Vergeleken met mijn studiegenoten ben ik niet de geniaalste wiskundige, die titel moet ik aan anderen laten. Mijn kracht ligt meer in het analytisch denken. Ook het grotere plaatje of de rode draad in het oog houden zou ik omschrijven als mijn kracht. Ik werk graag samen met anderen, die juist wiskundig heel erg de diepte in gaan, waar ik de brug kan vormen tussen de diepte, en de opdracht als geheel. Ik hoop op korte termijn een baan te vinden waar ik deze kwaliteiten kan gebruiken en me verder kan ontwikkelen. Denkt u dat mijn profiel bij uw vacature past, dan hoor ik dat graag!

Naast mijn studie ben ik samen met Mark Keijzer oprichter van Sjark Boxes. Wij zijn een bedrijf dat unieke kerstpakkettenverzorgt. Onze pakketten zijn volledig gepersonaliseerd verpakt, met een inhoud van lokale producten. Geen enorme doos gevuld met goedkope spullen, maar juist alleen maar dingen waar je blij van wordt. Ik geloof er heilig in dat werknemers aan alles merken dat in onze pakketten moeite en aandacht is gestoken, en dat dat enorm gewaardeerd wordt! Neem daarom een kijkje op onze website, of neem contact met me op.

https://sjarkboxes.nl/

summary:
I am a Health Economics student at Erasmus University in Rotterdam. 

My focus on healthcare started while I studied in Canada for a semester, I followed an introductory course in Health Economics and set out to focus on that field of study. This is why I started my master in Health Economics at the Erasmus University in Rotterdam in September 2021. I kept asking myself the question: What would a transparent healthcare system look like? 

To learn more about the field of healthcare and what it is like to work in a hospital, I worked at the CWZ hospital in Nijmegen, on topics such as e-health, patient satisfaction and user friendly patient portals. 

Next to healthcare, economics is a topic close to my heart. Because of this, I was a member of Rethinking Economics NL. Here, I hosted the Rethinking Podcast, which you can find on the website of Rethinking Economics NL, where I got to talk to experts in the economic field that can change your perspective, if youâ€™re willing to listen. These experts were from many fields and all over the world, with interesting topics for everyone. 

Another organization I closely worked with is Our New Economy, a for-purpose organization that wants to propel forward into the new economy, and put the wellbeing of citizens at the centre of the economy. With them I worked on creating educational material and an online workshop about the New Economy. 

Around all this is my love for reading and my curiosity for people. I would like to finish with the fact that I like to listen. If you want to link and chat, or if you are up for a cup of tea, let's share stories and learn from one another. I am a village girl who is living in the city, if you look me in the eyes, I will say Hi, because that is the kind of person I am. 

If you have read this far, thank you. I cannot wait to talk to you.

name: Yasmine Van der Straten
degree 1: Master of Philosophy - MPhil, Cum Laude
skills: ['English', 'Public Speaking', 'Economics', 'Law', 'Teaching', 'Research']
summary:
I am a PhD Candidate in Finance at the University of Amsterdam and Tinbergen Institute and a visiting PhD-scholar at De Nederlandsche Bank. My supervisors are Prof. Dr. E.C. Perotti and Prof. Dr. F. Van der Ploeg. My research is in climate finance and focuses on understanding the effects of financial frictions on effective strategies for addressing climate change.  I have two main areas of study:

In my work on climate change adaptation, I examine the relationship between financial constraints and optimal adaptation to physical climate risk at the household level.  I study the dynamic consequences on housing, income, and wealth inequality, and evaluate the design and political feasibility of policies aimed at alleviating the effects associated with financial constraints.
As financial factors shape the transition to a sustainable and low-carbon economy, I also study the interaction between financial frictions and climate transition risk at the corporate level. I examine how these frictions affect the pace of the green transition and explore the impact on the pricing and ownership dynamics of corporate bonds.

I hold an MPhil in Economics from Tinbergen Institute (with distinction), a Bachelor of Science in Economics (with highest distinction) and a Bachelor in Law from Erasmus University Rotterdam. 

Visit my personal webpage via: https://www.yasminevanderstraten.com

degree 2: International Bachelor Economics and Business economics
skills: ['ESG Reporting', 'ESG Steering', 'Teamwork', 'Microsoft Office', 'English', 'Social Media', 'Economics', 'Research', 'Project Management', 'Financial Accounting', 'Management Accounting', 'International Relations', 'Public Relations', 'Business Strategy', 'Strategic Planning', 'Social Networking', 'Corporate Social Responsibility', 'Financial Advisory', 'Customer Relationship Management (CRM)', 'Financial Modeling']
summary:
I am an entrepreneurial, analytical, and engaged corporate performance management consultant. My friends and colleagues describe me as proactive, creative, and trustworthy. In my relationship with others, integrity, openness, and joy are of great importance to me. 

 If I may paraphrase Barack Obama, it does not matter to me what wealth, status, power, or fame we have, what truly matters is how well we have loved and what small part we play in making the lives of other people better. With that in mind, not only will we thrive, but it will bring everyone's #wellbeing, and that of the planet, to a liveable standard for generations to come. 

Ever since I can remember, I enjoy solving puzzles, and that is exactly what I do. Whether it is connecting people with people across different networks and organisations at Wellbeing Economy Alliance Nederland or connecting the dots in complex business data flows at cpmview, I love creating synergies and insights that previously did not exist, bringing a collective vision to collective action. 

I want companies to transition to better #sustainablebusinessmanagement. But how can they do that, with all these time-consuming manual reporting processes, affecting the integrity of their financial and sustainability data? Not being able to make reliable strategic decisions? 

With the changing regulatory landscape for reporting processes, companies face many challenges regarding #datagovernance. Integrating financial and #sustainabilityreporting, and streamlining reporting processes for two equally important drivers of business performance, will prevent disconnected processes, saving both time and money. Ultimately, leading to more confident and satisfied employees. It allows them to trust their data and gain better insights into their business operation and performance, leading to #sustainablebusinessmanagement.

Having self-confidence in your skills also helps you use English more effectively:  communicate fluently, easily express yourself in conversation and presenting to a group.  In addition, a range of knowledge, literature, art, and social awareness becomes available for your own use.

summary:
Hi, I am Dr. Lieke Verheijen, assistant professor in Communication and Information Studies at Radboud University in Nijmegen, the Netherlands, as well as program director of the master CIW there. I am also one of the five members of the Spelling Committee of the Dutch Language Union ('Taalunie').

My research is about language use in personal and professional computer-mediated communication, as well as its impact on literacy, and particularly the use of emoji in CMC.

I have obtained degrees in English Language and Culture (BA & MA, both cum laude), Language and Communication (Research Master, summa cum laude), and Dutch Applied Linguistics (PhD).

My skills, besides research in linguistics, include data analysis, (academic) writing, editing, translation, teaching, research/information/time/self-/project management, project/strategic/event planning, events organisation, problem solving, analytical skills, critical thinking, presentation skills, public speaking, teamwork, and interpersonal skills.

name: Suzanne Peraino
field of studies 1: English and American Language and Literature
field of studies 2: English and American Language and Literature
summary:
My current professional focus and research:
 Inter-cultural awareness and pedagogical skills in the EAP classroom, specifically focusing on Chinese academic degree-seekers in Anglophone programs and academies.

Since 2010, following from my ancillary university focus on Chinese language and culture, I and my colleagues Dr. Mark Vitullo and Dr. Yao (Amy) Hsiao have been involved in several projects relating to Chinese exchange students and their English language acquisition and production skills within the Anglophone academic environment (specifically EAP writing/oral skills at Tilburg University). We are currently exploring the practical English language acquisition and production difficulties with which these students struggle and which hinder their success in Anglophone programs. 

Our goal is twofold:
1)	 To offer EAP (English for academic purposes) university teachers information about certain Chinese (Mandarin) language characteristics, Chinese rhetorical essay structures and logical conventions of idea development that Chinese exchange students learn in China. This information should enable the EAP teacher to identity and modify potential interference patterns during EAP courses.
2)	To develop practical classroom methods to support and coach Chinese exchange students more efficiently and effectively so that they can acquire the academic English skills they need to succeed in the global, primarily Anglophone, academic environment. 
My academic interest in this has its root in my Bachelorâ€™s education in Asian Studies, as well as my current work with Chinese PhD candidates at Tilburg University.

During my undergraduate education, I took several courses in Mandarin Chinese. I have now resumed Mandarin language classes to gain a better insight into basic Mandarin  structures and pronunciation.

name: Michael Glennon
skills: ['Research', 'Lesgeven', 'Management', 'Hoger onderwijs', 'Sociologie']
summary:
I work in several areas: language coaching and scientific writing support for students and professionals, teaching social theory and social scientific research methods to students in higher education, and exploring the relationship between language and society with a particular emphasis on the subject of children and linguistic diversity in European urban areas.
  
Language Coaching and Writing Support: I provide language coaching for groups and individuals seeking  improvement and greater confidence in their use of academic English. I also offer support services for professionals and students working on specific scientific writing and/or formal academic English language texts, e.g. scientific articles, dissertations, theses, lectures and presentations, reports, proposals and etcetera. Additionally, I offer translation of reports, white papers or other documents for education and research.
 
E-learning, Sociology, and Higher Education: I possess more than twelve years of experience in online instruction. This experience includes teaching sociology at a college level to a wide variety of students for universities and colleges in the American Midwest, and the development of original online courses covering a wide range of topics relevant to the social sciences. Presently my course design efforts focus on enhancing the accessibility of course content. Making sure content is accessible not only to people with different learning styles, but also to people with impairments.   

Researcher and Social Scientist: I have specialized education and experience in the use of ethnographic and discourse analytic research methods. In the past I applied these skills to a social scientific research  on the subject of community based services for people with intellectual disabilities, and to the cultural politics of autism and autistic rights. Presently I am designing a framework for a comparative analysis of experiences raising multilingual children in the Netherlands and Germany.

name: Anna Kaal
skills: ['Teaching', 'English', 'Linguistics', 'Literature', 'Dutch', 'Translation', 'Journalism', 'Research', 'Language Teaching', 'Qualitative Research', 'Editing', 'Academic Writing', 'Lecturing', 'Intercultural Communication']
summary:
As a teacher educator and researcher at the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam, I work with pre-service and in-service teachers to translate knowledge about language and language learning to their (foreign) language classrooms. An essential theme in my work is the notion â€˜language awarenessâ€™, which can perhaps best be described as â€˜looking at the world through linguistic glassesâ€™ â€“ which knowledge about language do we all need in order to think critically about, but also enjoy, the language we use? I am also interested in the way (student) teachers reflect on their practice. 

I studied English language and culture (MA) and Communication and Information Sciences (BA) at the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam. I continued with a PhD in cognitive linguistics on the use of metaphor in  conversations. After obtaining an Educational MA, I taught English and Literature to secondary school students for 4 years.

At the moment I am teaching in our educational master programmes on the topics of narrativity and LA and their potential for language classrooms, on language pedagogy and general pedagogy and on teacher reflection. I am co-supervising two PhDs on language education and teacher and learner language awareness. I am working on metaphor elicitation to raise studentsâ€™ language awareness and teachersâ€™ perceptions of practice; other research includes the use of goal system reflection.   

Through organizing conferences and working with professional learning communities of (student) teachers me and my colleagues try to close the gap between theory and practice. I was one of the main organizers of the 2017 conference â€˜Look both ways: narrative and metaphor in educationâ€™ (an edited volume stemming from this conference was published with Routledge) and the ALA2018 conference â€˜Towards Language Aware Citizenshipâ€™.

summary:
I'm a writer. 

For 30 years I wrote everything, and anything, whatever washed up on my aimless path - not even a path. More of a ruddlerless jazz-type voyage from one pit-bull of an idea to the next. These are some of the things that I wroteâ€¦

* features, interviews, news stuff, funny stuff, for a whole motley variety of magazines and websites
* Radio 4 comedy scripts
* book reviews, film reviews, toaster reviews, sex toy reviews
* dictionary definitions
* a poem about an alcoholic superfish
* a couple of suitably ironic songs about Jesus
* an online business English course for Italians
* a whole e-learning platform ... thing. I donâ€™t know. It was a long time ago.
* a guide book for a virtual world
* a long-standing faux online identity (faux is a very nice word. Sounds sweet. Sexy almost. Much better than fake.) 
* translations for an Italian toiletries manufacturer

I also edited books and newsletters and I worked as a sub-editor for a while. Oh, and taught English for twenty years. And wrote four novels. All the while drifting like a feather. In a beautiful world. 

But as of March 2016, all that has changed. For in March 2016, I found focus. 

Now I'm catching up with the world and going online. Full immersion. Making a living from the skills I've accidentally built up over the past 30 years. Digital nomad. All that. How nomadic I'll be remains to be seen. How much of a living I'll make remains to be seen. But I've started. And I'm focused. 

What I'm doing on LinkedIn I have no idea. It just ground me down in the end. Like a bird pecking at your scalp for ten whole years. OK, OK. I'm in. Now what do you need?

name: Anna-Alexandra Marhold
skills: ['Public International Law', 'International Law', 'European Union', 'Politics', 'Human Rights', 'European Law', 'Policy', 'International Trade', 'International Relations', 'Political Science', 'Dutch', 'International Human Rights', 'Russian', 'Foreign Policy', 'Policy Analysis', 'International Organizations', 'International Humanitarian Law', 'Diplomacy', 'Public Policy', 'International Development']
summary:
I am Assistant Professor at the Grotius Centre for International Legal Studies at Leiden Law School, the Netherlands and a Visiting Professor at Vermont Law and Graduate School (VT, USA).

My specializations are International Economic Law, World Trade Organization (WTO) and International Trade Law and the interaction with international and European energy law and regulation.

I am particularly interested in the ongoing crisis in international trade law; security interests and other non-strictly trade-related objectives in international trade law; EU Energy Policy and its interaction with WTO obligations; European energy security, energy and environmental regulation in Preferential Trade Agreements (PTAs); the future of the Energy Charter Treaty; the OPEC cartel; law and economics approaches to energy regulation; the sustainable energy transition; access to supplies and natural resources; public goods; regulation of network industries; squaring energy security with sustainable development and consumer protection; regulation of transit of energy; the Energy Community Treaty and European external energy relations, particularly with the European Neighborhood.

Keywords: 

- International Trade and WTO Law, Economics and Policy
- International and European Energy Law
- Law and Economics
- International Investment Law
- Public International Law
- Natural Resources Law
- Environmental Law and Sustainable Development
- WTO, Energy Charter Treaty
- PTAs and Mega-Regionals
- EU External Relations Law and Energy, Energy Community Treaty

I am a curious and passionate person who believes in the strength of human relations, no matter what. I consider myself a traveller. I do love travelling and discovering new places by walking and carrying a disproportionate and heavy backpack, knowing that for the long day I will be outside. Besides that, even when I am locked in my room, my mind has already reached many other places that I would never imagine. 

This has been strengthened by my previous experiences abroad. Originally from Italy, I spent part of my third academic year studying at KU Leuven in Leuven, Belgium. Leuven was a revelatory experience that showed me that I love international settings, which is to say engaging with people who have different backgrounds and adventures. 

 Upon my graduation at the University of Perugia, Italy, I spent almost two months living in Istanbul, Turkey. There, I was doing a traineeship that allowed me to work with an international group of people. It boosted my empathy, cross-cultural sensitivity and teamworking skills. Not satisfied, I moved to Brussels for another traineeship, at the Umbria Region - Brussels Office, which allowed me to enter into the 'Brussels bubble' and acquired insights of networking, policy-making process, lobby activities. For that reason, I ended up in Maastricht to study European Studies, specialisation in Global Challenges. 

My drivers? Hard willingness, cross-cultural values, dynamism, perseverance and strong beliefs!

summary:
Kocku von Stuckrad is Professor of Religious Studies at the University of Groningen, the Netherlands. He has published extensively on topics related to the cultural history of religion, science, and philosophy in Europe and North America.

Professor von Stuckrad served as President of the International Society for the Study of Religion, Nature, and Culture (ISSRNC) and as President of the Dutch Association for the Study of Religion (NGG). He also was a founding board member of the European Society for the Study of Western Esotericism (ESSWE). He was co-chair of the Critical Theory and Discourses on Religion Group, as well as the Religion in Europe Group, of the American Academy of Religion. In 2011 he was appointed as Honorary Professor of the Study of Religion at Aarhus University, Denmark. From 2013â€“2017, he served as the Dean of the Faculty of Theology and Religious Studies, University of Groningen.

Together with Whitney A. Bauman, he is co-founder and co-director of Counterpoint: Navigating Knowledge, a research center and information hub, located at the interface of academic and non-academic knowledge practices and traditions.

name: Gerasimos Tsourapas
position 2: Senior Lecturer (Associate Professor) in Middle East Politics
degree 2: Summer Program in Arabic (Modern Standard & Egyptian Colloquial)
summary:
Gerasimos Tsourapas works on the international relations of the Middle East and the broader Global South, with a particular focus on the politics of migrants, refugees, and diasporas. He has secured research funding in excess of Â£1.35 million, and is currently the Principal Investigator of a five-year European Research Council Starting Grant project on migration diplomacy. He is a Senior Fellow of the UK Higher Education Academy, and has been elected as the incoming Chair of the Ethnicity, Nationalism, & Migration Studies (ENMISA) Section of the International Studies Association (2023â€“25).

Dr Tsourapas is the author of The Politics of Migration in Modern Egypt â€“ Strategies for Regime Survival in Autocracies (Cambridge University Press, 2018) and Migration Diplomacy in the Middle East and North Africa â€“ Power, Mobility, and the State (Manchester University Press, 2021). He co-edited, with Prof Maria Koinova, a special issue on 'Diasporas and Sending States in World Politics' for International Political Science Review. His work has also appeared in International Studies Quarterly, European Journal of International Relations, International Migration Review, Journal of Ethnic and Migration Studies, and other leading journals.

Dr Tsourapas has received numerous awards. The Politics of Migration in Modern Egypt was awarded the 2020 ENMISA Distinguished Book Award by the International Studies Association and was shortlisted for the British International Studies Association's L.H.M. Ling Outstanding First Book Prize. His work has also been recognised by the American Political Science Association (Best Dissertation on Migration & Citizenship, 2016), the International Studies Association (Martin O. Heisler Award, 2017), and the Middle East Studies Association of North America (Graduate Student Paper Prize, 2015). He also received the inaugural 2021 ENMISA Emerging Scholar Award by the International Studies Association. 

Dr Tsourapas served as a Fellow at the Center for European Studies, Harvard University (2019â€“20) and The American University in Cairo (2013â€“14). He received a BA in Economics and Political Science from Yale University (2006), an MSc in International Political Economy from the London School of Economics and Political Science (2007), and a PhD in Politics from SOAS, University of London (2016).

summary:
I guess I always saw myself as a storyteller.  That's why, when I was a kid, I memorised bits from the movies, books and comedians I admired until I was ready to make up my own. It's also why I got degrees in media and literature and ended up working in journalism before I found myself in a great place for anyone who likes telling stories. 

As a teacher, I get to tell stories about culture and communication to international students, and I get to create and carry out communication courses that help them to tell their own stories.

As a Public Relations professional, I try to tell the story of European Studies to anyone who will listen, in person, online and in print, because I'm proud to be a part of a unique international and interdisciplinary programme that prepares young Europeans for a wide range of careers while giving them knowledge and skills that will enable them to adapt to a changing labour market. 

Like a lot of storytellers, I can't sit still for very long, so I'm always on the lookout for opportunities, so if you need someone to help you tell your story, all you have to do is ask.

name: Dimitris Bouris
field of studies 1: The European Union's role in the Palestinian state-building after the Oslo Accords
skills: ['International Relations', 'European politics', 'Politics', 'Middle East', 'Conflict Resolution', 'Euro-Mediterranean Relations', 'State-building', 'Security Sector Refom', 'Judiciary Sector Reform', 'Human Rights', 'EU', 'Political Science', 'Diplomacy', 'Foreign Policy', 'Research', 'French', 'Policy Analysis', 'European Affairs', 'Foreign Affairs', 'European Union']
summary:
Dr Dimitris Bouris is a Senior Lecturer at the Department of Political Science at the University of Amsterdam and a Jean Monnet Chair "The EU as a Global Actor" (ATHENA). He is an Associate Editor of the academic journal European Security and a Visiting Professor at the College of Europe (Natolin). He is also the leader and coordinator of the EU-Middle East Jean Monnet Network EUMENIA (www.eumenia.eu). Dr Bouris is a co-leader of the Europe in the World theme of the Amsterdam Centre for European Studies (ACES), an Academic Board member of the Amsterdam Centre for Middle Eastern Studies (ACMES), an Academic Council Member of the European Neighbourhood Council and a non-resident fellow at the Hellenic Foundation for European and Foreign Policy ELIAMEP. 

His research focus lies at the intersection of International Relations (IR theory, peacebuilding, state-building, security sector reform, conflict resolution), EU Studies (EU External Relations, EU Common Security and Defence Policy) and Middle East and North Africa Studies. Dr Bouris is the author of â€œThe European Union and Occupied Palestinian Territories: State-building without a Stateâ€ (Routledge, 2014). Dimitris is also the co-editor (with Tobias Schumacher) of the â€œRevised European Neighbourhood Policy: Continuity and Change in EU Foreign Policyâ€ (Palgrave Macmillan, 2017) and the co-editor (with Daniela Huber and Michelle Pace) of the â€œRoutledge Handbook of EU-Middle East Relationsâ€ (Routledge, 2022). He has also edited special issues and published a number of scholarly articles in leading peer-reviewed academic journals such as European Security, the Hague Journal on the rule of law, Mediterranean Politics, Global Affairs, International Spectator, the British Journal of Politics and International Relations, International Political Sociology and Geopolitics. He is also a frequent media commentator an has published a number of policy briefs and op-eds for major European and Middle East news and policy outlets such as EUROMESCO, Al Jazeera, Carnegie Endowment for International Peace and Open Democracy.

name: Jens Emmers
skills: ['Engels', 'Research', 'Internationale relaties', 'Politiek', 'Spreken in het openbaar', 'Internationale organisaties', 'Mensenrechten', 'Beleidsanalyse', 'Wetenschap', 'Oost-Europa', 'Verkiezingen']
summary:
The American writer and anthropologist Zora Neale Hurston once said â€œresearch is formalized curiosity. It is poking and prying with a purposeâ€. It is this same curiosity that characterizes me and my work.
Ever since I was little, I have been driven by an endless curiosity for knowledge, especially with regards to international affairs and Eastern European affairs, and I strongly believe that research, whether in an academic or professional capacity, is an continuous opportunity for personal and intellectual development. 

Working in an international think tank environment and having worked on projects in Hungary, Kyrgyzstan, China and South Africa, I am comfortable applying my analytical capabilities in a fast-paced work environment and to accomodate to changing circumstances.

name: Gertjan Hoetjes
skills: ['Research', 'Conferences', 'Analysis', 'Politics', 'Political Economy', 'European politics', 'European Affairs', 'Middle East', 'Budgeting', 'Telephone Skills', 'Reception', 'International Economics', 'Publications', 'Dutch', 'Government', 'Writing', 'International Relations', 'English', 'Journalism', 'Event Management']
summary:
Currently I am a lecturer in European Studies at the University of Amsterdam. In this position I am jointly convening several courses revolving around EU Enlargement and External Relations, European Geopolitics, European Integration and Skills Seminar Brussels. In addition, I have taught seminars for the course Middle East: History, Politics and Economy and am a MA thesis supervisor. I have several years of experience as a module convenor of a variety of courses in both the United Kingdom (Durham University) and the Netherlands (University of Groningen). In these courses I have covered several subjects such as politics, political economy, state-society relations and international relations in the Middle East as well as supervising Bachelor and Master Students in Middle Eastern Studies (University of Groningen) and Politics (Durham University). Throughout these years I have distinguished myself as a lecturer by implementing active learning methods in my courses, which has resulted in excellent student reviews about the quality of my teaching. 

As a scholar my research revolves around state-society relations, political economy and international relations in the Gulf region. I obtained my doctoral degree in Middle Eastern Politics at the University in Exeter in March 2020 (after passing the Viva without corrections) with a thesis on the the impact of Internet technology on the Gulf monarchies focusing on Kuwait and Oman. I have presented my work at various conferences and had a number of publications in the International Spectator, edited volumes, Gulf Insight, the HH Sheikh Nasser Mohammad al-Sabah Publication Series and ZemZem. Alongside this,  I have frequently contributed to Gulf State News providing political analysis on Kuwait and have initiated several extra-cirricular activies including being co-organiser of the Gulf Conference 2016 (University of Exeter) and co-founding the Social Movement Theory Reading Group at the University of Exeter.

summary:
I am a biologist by education. I approach the world with curiosity and like to learn new things. I have a PhD in neuroscience and many years experience in research, but I also have been a high school teacher. I like to help people. Communication and interaction between people fascinates me just like communication between neurons. People value my optimistic view on life. I like to teach, I like to present and perform and I like to write. I have a good eye for detail and I work carefully.

I am interested in people. During my life I have learned to use empathy and attentiveness to support, encourage and inspire people. I am a good listener and like to discover what motivates and drives people by asking the right questions.

Plasticity of the nervous system is crucial for organisms to adapt to changing environments. At the same time rigidity of synaptic connections is important for reliable neuronal communication. Which mechanisms are at work in neurons to optimize communication and information processing? How can learning be accomplished and memory be stored?
I have performed electrophysiology on invertebrate and vertebrate neurons to study changes in excitability, synaptic plasticity and regeneration after damage. Knowledge about signal processing will teach us more about the functioning of the brain. And about communication in general.

General skills
-Teaching & presentation, writing & communication skills.
-Coaching skills.
-Leadership and project management skills.
-Computer and data analysis skills.
-Languages: Dutch, English, German and French.

Scientific skills
â€¢Electrophysiological techniques.
â€¢Experience with writing scientific texts.
â€¢Immunocytochemistry, confocal microscopy.
â€¢Observation and analysis of animal behavior.

summary:
Play is an essential element in our lives but too often we think that play is childish. A quick look shows us the opposite. Sports, music, movies, theatre helps us to understand life. Hence play makes us open in our forward rushing lives. 
The love for sports in any form, active or passive, is one of the best accessible ways to re-connect with the playfulness in our lives.
At the moment I prepare my PhD, on this matter. I write, speak, listen and teach about it. I develop lectures and training materials.
As a senior lecturer at the University of the Arts at Utrecht NL. HKU, I co-teach to develop this connection between philosophy of play in life and sports.
Happy to share it with you.

summary:
Ik ben een masterstudent Fiscaal Recht(Directe Belastingen) aan de Erasmus Universiteit. Mijn interesse in de fiscaliteit begon op de middelbare school. Zo heb ik voor mijn profielwerkstuk onderzoek gedaan naar de verschillen tussen de belastingen in Nederland en het Verenigd Koninkrijk. Dat was mijn eerste ervaring met de fiscaliteit. In het eerste jaar van mijn bachelor behoor ik tot de 10% beste studenten van de opleiding. In het tweede jaar van mijn bachelor lag de focus meer op de fiscaliteit, waardoor mijn cijfers aanzienlijk hoger zijn dan in het eerste jaar. Hierdoor behoor ik tot de beste studenten in het tweede jaar. 

Echter zijn er belangrijkere dingen in het leven dan hoge resultaten. Zo probeer ik tijdens mijn studie mijn motivatie en kennis te delen met mijn medestudenten, zodat we met zâ€™n allen succesvol de studie kunnen afronden. 

Momenteel ben ik werkzaam bij PwC als werkstudent International Tax Services. Voorheen ben ik werkzaam geweest op de afdeling Middle Market bij PwC.

Altijd bereikbaar voor eventuele vragen. Schroom dus niet om een bericht te sturen!

name: Yuri van Buul
summary:
Ik ben een masterstudent Fiscaal Recht en Rechtsgeleerdheid aan Tilburg University. Voor mijn masteropleiding heb ik de bacheloropleiding Fiscaal Recht aan Tilburg University afgerond. Tijdens mijn fiscale studies heb ik interesses ontwikkeld in de deelgebieden van transfer pricing, estate planning, (fiscaal) strafrecht en (belasting)procesrecht. Alhoewel het een divers palet aan interesses zijn, is de gemene deler dat bij ieder deelgebied een nauwe samenwerking met de cliÃ«nt gewenst is.

Naast mijn studie ben ik actief lid geweest van de Tilburgse Fiscalisten Vereniging De Smeetskring. Als Vakliteratuurcommissie zetten mijn commissiegenoten en ik ons in om een fiscaal-inhoudelijke bijdrage te leveren aan onze vereniging door het organiseren van vakinhoudelijke bijeenkomsten, zowel zelfstandig als in samenwerking met onze partners.

Verder heb ik naast mijn studie nog een bijbaan als administratief-secretarieel medewerker bij Klikkelstein Kinderopvang. Bij deze bijbaan word ik breed ingezet binnen de bedrijfsvoering, waarbij ik een grote diversiteit aan administratieve werkzaamheden uitvoer. De ervaring in de commerciÃ«le zijde van een onderneming is een waardevolle toevoeging op mijn achtergrond als fiscaal jurist.

name: Jan Vink
skills: ['Bedrijfsopvolging en bedrijfsoverdracht', 'Belastingadvies', 'Het voeren van bezwaar- en beroepsprocedures']
summary:
Je bodyguard in belastingzaken

Wie ben ik?
Met bijna 30 jaar ervaring in het fiscale werkveld ken ik de klappen van de zweep. Belasting moeten we allemaal betalen, ook als ondernemer, maar het liefst zo min mogelijk. Ik haal mijn voldoening uit het voorkomen en oplossen van problemen. Geen uitdaging in dit werkveld is mij te groot. Dat is ook mijn onderscheidend vermogen; ik ga verder waar andere adviseurs het opgeven en voorkom het ontstaan van problemen. Daarbij gebruik ik mijn contacten binnen de Belastingdienst en fingerspitzengefÃ¼hl; weten wanneer je op welk moment iets wel of niet moet doen en op welke manier.

Wat doe ik?
Ik ondersteun jou als ondernemer en DGA om fiscaal alles in goede banen te leiden. Niet schimmig, maar met een open vizier. Ik bijt mij vast en speur net zolang totdat ik een oplossing heb gevonden, of het nu gaat om een bedrijfsoverdracht, het begeleiden van een boekenonderzoek door de Belastingdienst of het herstructureren van de onderneming. Ik zal een concreet voorbeeld geven.
Een transportonderneming had in het verleden een flink incidenteel fiscaal verlies opgelopen. Met een jaarlijkse omzet van â‚¬ 120.000, een salaris voor de DGA van â‚¬ 60.000 en overige kosten van â‚¬ 50.000 zou de DGA 35 jaar bezig zijn om dit verlies weg te werken. Voor die tijd zijn die verliezen al voor het grootste deel verdampt en heb je daar dus niets meer aan. Voor deze DGA heb ik de onderneming zo fiscaal vormgegeven, dat hij de verliezen wel tijdig kon gebruiken en de eerste jaren helemaal geen belasting meer hoefde te betalen; een besparing van tienduizenden euro's.

Dit levert het je op
Een fiscaal gezonde onderneming waarbij de fiscale zaken allemaal in orde zijn.
Rust; je hebt naar fiscale zaken geen omkijken meer, omdat ik die je uit handen genomen heb en permanent bewaak, zodat jij kunt doen waar je goed in bent: ondernemen.

In 1998 ben ik afgestudeerd in Nederlands recht, onderdeel Civiel Recht. Daarnaast heb ik van de richting Strafrecht meerdere vakken met goed resultaat voltooid. 

Vervolgens ben ik bij de Belastingdienst gaan werken en heb mij bekwaamd in fiscaal recht, met als specialisme omzetbelasting, middels interne cursussen en opleidingen. Tevens heb ik van de opleiding Fiscaal Recht, het doctoraal Fiscaal Recht met het accent Indirecte Belastingen met goed resultaat voltooid. De modulen van laatstgenoemde opleiding heb ik gevolgd aan de Universiteiten Maastricht, Tilburg en Amsterdam.Tevens heb ik bij de Belastingdienst o.a de interne cursus procederen en cursussen op het gebied van het Formele Recht gevolgd. 

Van 2010 tot oktober 2013 was ik secretaris van de Kennisgroep Vrijstellingen, Overheid en Landbouw. 

Voorts ben ik van 1 januari 2010 tot                                      3 oktober 2019 lid van voornoemde kennisgroep geweest.

In 2013 ben ik gaan werken als Belastinginspecteur en Kantoorsenior/Vaktechnisch adviseur omzetbelasting (VTA), MKB van kantoor Leiden. 

Vanaf 17 april 2015 ben ik in verband met de sluiting van Belastingkantoor Leiden gaan werken als VTA van kantoor Hoofddorp, afdeling Arbeid en Dienstverlening, MKB. 

Sinds 1 maart 2019 ben ik werkzaam als VTA omzetbelasting, MKB, voor kantoor Den Haag.

Huidige werkzaamheden: procederen, interne controles, reviews, aansturen OB team v.w.b. fiscale vaktechiek (o.a initiÃ«ren en voorzitten jurisprudentie-overleggen, behandelen btw-technische complexe posten en begeleiden van de medewerkers. Ook begeleid ik in voorkomende gevallen stagiaires op hbo en universitair niveau, o.a. scriptiebegeleiding. 

Ik vind omzetbelasting nog steeds een mooi en uitdagend middel en ik deel mijn ervaring graag met nieuwe en ervaren collega' en hoop hen te motiveren en inspireren.

skills: ['Ecology', 'Water', 'Ecohydrology', 'Urban Ecohydrology', 'Sustainability', 'Remote sensing', 'Population Dynamics', 'Marine Biology', 'Dutch', 'English', 'Qualitative Research', 'Quantitative Research', 'Presentations', 'Academic Writing', 'Tutoring', 'Teaching']
summary:
I believe that water is an ideal medium to enhance system thinking. Water is central to everybody, for direct consumption, food, energy, hygiene, safety, and the balance of our ecosystems. And these water services need to be shared. I want to help create a world where we understand our interdependences, where we strengthen each otherâ€™s livelihoods in a sustainable way, creating peace rather than conflict, on the short and the long term, using holistic water management as a paradigm.  
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
I have a MSc. in Ecohydrology. I have worked on multiple projects and policies in the Netherlands, Poland, and Brazil using an intergrative (eco)system approach, involving hydrology, ecology, hydraulics, remote sensing, and GIS. I have worked in the public and humanitarian sector. Since 2020, I am working as a policy advisor at the Hoogheemraadschap Hollands Noorderkwartier, a Dutch water board. 

In addition to my job, I am an active member of the Water Youth Network and Wetskills. I believe youth should be better represented at international water events and stages, because 1. we can make new connections, 2. we bring innovations, 3. we bring motivation and energy, and 4. we are the stakeholder of the future.

summary:
| Research | Epidemiology | Cardiovascular Disease | Diabetes Mellitus | Science | Health |

I am interested in investigating disease patterns and causes of disease in humans. My passion for epidemiology was ignited when a close neighbour told me about the famous story of Dr. John Snow and the Mystery of the Broad Street Pump.

I am currently working as a PhD Student at Amsterdam UMC / VU University Amsterdam, department of Epidemiology & Data Science. The focus of my research is to study the role of arterial calcification patterns as risk factors for (non-)atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease in patients with diabetes mellitus type 2.

I followed my passion by following a master's program Epidemiology at Maastricht University. In 2021, I have successfully completed this master's program. This degree enables me to conduct scientific research focusing on the distribution and determinants of health-related states and events in specified populations, and the application of this study to the control of health problems.

In 2020, I graduated from the Vrije Universiteit (VU) of Amsterdam where I followed a two-year master's program Cardiovascular Research. This degree enables me to conduct scientific research focusing on prevention, pathogenesis, diagnosis and therapy of cardiovascular diseases. 

I previously studied Medical Natural Sciences, which is a bachelor's program also offered by the VU University. This program focusses on translating research into the fundamentals of physics, biology and chemistry into innovative solutions for healthcare.

I am always eager to learn!

summary:
My name is Bram and I am a fourth year International Bachelor History student at ESHCC. While studying I have specialised in Economic History and take particular interest in international economic relations and international finance from national perspectives. Currently, I'm writing my bachelor thesis on the topic of De Nederlandsche Bank's discount rate policy in the period 1875-1914.

Following my bachelor's degree, I want to complete a Research Master in (Economic) History and eventually obtain a PhD in the field of financial history. More specifically, I hope to one day research monetary history and the evolution of central banking. Besides financial history, I take interest in the debate on how the use of history can help or harm policy making and hope to one day contribute to the debate on how history and policy can be combined.

Opzoek naar een nieuwe kans! Enthousiaste, betrokken geschiedenis docent met een hart voor haar leerling en passie voor haar vak zoekt een baan. MMA, burgerschap of geschiedenis maar ik sta open voor verassingen! 

Mijn naam is Maartje Samsen. Ik ben 23 jaar oud en woon in het prachtige Ommen. Alles wat ik doe draait om verbinding, waardering en creativiteit. Ik vind het geweldig om samen te werken met mensen, nieuwe ideeÃ«n uit te werken en mensen in hun kracht te zetten. Ik sta graag voor een grote groep mensen maar vindt het ook leuk om door middel van individuele coaching iemand verder te helpen. Dit is ook de reden dat ik met heel veel plezier docent en mentor ben geweest. Het maken van projecten en het uitwerken van lessen vind ik heel erg leuk. Moeilijke stof makkelijk, betekenisvol en zelfs leuk maken is een uitdaging die ik graag aan ga! Ik heb voor het vak geschiedenis gekozen omdat ik de verhalen prachtig vind. Door te kijken naar het verleden kan je het over alle onderwerpen hebben: je persoonlijke doelen of wensen maar ook pittige maatschappelijke thema's als discriminatie en oorlog. Geschiedenis gaat over politiek, economie, levensovertuiging, sociale verhoudingen, maatschappelijke constructen kortom over het leven wat wij als mensen leven. Persoonlijk ontwikkel ik me graag op creatief gebied en ben net begonnen aan een deeltijd kleinkunst opleiding en dans ik meerdere uren in de week. Leren is voor mij niet iets wat stopt naar je school, het is een levenshouding.

name: Jur Berghout
skills: ['Lossen', 'Afsluiten', 'Management', 'Lessen']
summary:
Even voorstellen. Ik ben Jur Berghout en zit in mijn laatste jaar van mijn Bachelor studie Geschiedenis docent aan de Hogeschool Rotterdam. Voor deze studie, bevind ik mij op het moment in Zweden om daar een onderzoek te doen naar het Zweedse schoolsysteem. Daar staat centraal hoe wij, dit Scandinavische model als (jonge) docenten kunnen gebruiken in het Nederlandse onderwijs. Daarnaast ga ik vanaf januari 2023 weer aan de slag als LIO geschiedenisdocent bij Thorbecke Voortgezet Onderwijs. Afgelopen jaar heb ik daar met veel plezier stage gelopen en is deze stage omgezet in een (tijdelijke) baan als docent. 
Wat mij drijft om geschiedenis te geven aan jongeren is het feit dat we allemaal een andere kijk hebben op hedendaagse gebeurtenissen. Terwijl deze gebeurtenissen altijd zijn te verklaren wanneer we terug te kijken naar het verleden. 
Daarnaast heb ik vergevorderde interesse in zowel binnenlandse als de buitenlandse politiek. Ik heb dan ook meegedaan met nationale en regionale debatten. Deze passie voor de politiek en debat probeer ik dan ook mee te geven aan mijn leerlingen, doordat ik een keuzevak debatteren heb gestart.

summary: Historia magistra vitae. Geschiedenis is mijn grote passie. Het leert mij de mensen en de wereld te begrijpen. Het legt uit waarom alles vandaag is zoals het is. Het verklaart alle problemen en geeft daarvoor ook oplossingen, als je maar goed genoeg zoekt. Geschiedenis biedt zoveel inzicht in de menselijke wereld dat ik zo graag deze kunst van conflictoplossing met anderen wil delen. Ik zou willen dat iedereen hun eigen leven en het leven van anderen kan verbeteren en hun relaties kan verbeteren door middel van geschiedenis zoals ik dat geleerd heb. Het is soms werkelijk een wondermiddel. Andere mensen helpen is mijn drijfveer. Daarom wil ik graag mijn lessen van geschiedenis en de manieren om die zelf te ontdekken meegeven aan anderen. Kinderen staan aan het begin van de samenleving en onderwijs is dÃ© wortel van zowel kwaad als goed. Daarom is geschiedenis docent worden de beste baan voor mij en daar ben ik voor in opleiding. Verder wil ik door middel van schrijven voor het brede publiek de belangrijke verhalen verder delen. De geheimen van het verleden zouden niet alleen voor academici beschikbaar moeten zijn. Kan je niks met mijn LinkedIn maar heb je wel een vraag over jouw cultuur/politiek/familie of iets dergelijks? Vraag maar raak!

summary:
Iâ€™m Larae Malooly, a journalist, writer, editor, and powerful communicator based in The Netherlands. I research and write about science, sustainability, technology, and culture for mission-driven organisations like Metabolic and Elsevier.

Some of my favourite topics include regenerative agriculture, sustainable industry, digital product passports, issues such as scarce metals and SU plastic, and the intersection of grassroots conservation with top-down policy. 

My innate environmental and social conscience drives an analytical mindset and a penchant for translating topical issues into palatable and useful articles, websites, white papers, and reports. My specialty lies in grasping complex topics â€” such as systems, academic and scientific research, current affairs, and social trends â€” and weaving together an engaging story that everyone can understand. I use comprehensive research, interviewing skills, and lively storytelling methods to make engaging content. 

My copywriting skills include writing news articles, reports, online content, press releases, social media and creative texts, commercial materials, and ghostwriting books for organisations and private entities. 

Having been on-camera as a reporter and announcer for CBS in the United States, I enjoy engaging an audience and know how to create content that appeals to diverse groups. New experiences, cultures, and technological advances inspire me tremendously.

I am interested in how art and culture contribute to creating spaces for free expression, collective imagination, and global solidarity. How do the forces of art materialize in our different, yet deeply interconnected realities?

Â»Julia is amazingÂ« Annie Sprinkle

Â»culturele duizendpootÂ« Jeanne Prisser, de Volkskrant

Â»Perfectie is de standaard voor Julia van MourikÂ« Tineke Reijnders, Ons Erfdeel

BIO:
Julia van Mourik is a curator and editor. As director of The One Minutes Foundation, she leads the platform for experimental video art that works closely with various arts education institutions in the Netherlands and internationally. And as director of Lost & Found, she leads the artist salons: an eclectic mix of visual art, video, performance, outsider art, amateur art, music, literature, design, science and more.
She is a member of the Supervisory Board of CREA, member of the Advisory Committee Multi-Year Policy Plan for Art and Culture The Hague 2025-2028, chair of the Advisory Committee on Project Subsidies for Culture of the city of Utrecht and advisor to Amsterdam Fund for the Arts.

Before that she was, among other things, financial director of Top Publishers, which publishes the magazines Fantastic Man and The Gentle Woman, and executive editor of Re-Magazine. She held advisory and board positions for, among others, the Amsterdam Art Council, China Central Academy of Fine Arts, city of Amsterdam, Netherlands Architecture Fund, Netherlands Film Fund and ReykjavÃ­k International Film Festival.
Julia van Mourik studied Publicity and Culture in Amsterdam and did residencies at Raid Projects Gallery in Los Angeles and Townhouse Gallery in Cairo.

skills: ['Acting', 'Theatre', 'Film', 'Social Sciences', 'Research', 'Performing Arts', 'Performance Studies', 'Project Management', 'Performance Analysis', 'Dramaturgy', 'Directing', 'Cultural Analysis', 'Cultural Studies', 'Dutch', 'Art', 'Public Speaking', 'English']
summary:
Wigbertson Julian Isenia originates from the Island of Curacao and has an MA degree in Arts and Culture (University of Amsterdam) and two bachelorâ€™s, in interdisciplinary social sciences (University of Utrecht) and Theatre Studies (University of Amsterdam). During his MA, he received a scholarship from the Bekker-la Bastide fund, and the University of Amsterdam nominated him for the ECHO awards. In 2016 he conducted preliminary fieldwork research on same-sex lives and cultures on the island of CuraÃ§ao funded by the Sylva W. de Groot Fund and Stichting Fundatie van de Vrijvrouwe van Renswoude. 

He did his PhD at the University of Amsterdam on a Dutch national research council funded (NWO) research project. His PhD centres on the concept of sexual citizenship beyond their legal conceptualisation in CuraÃ§ao and Bonaire by analysing cultural articulations and practices such as archival collections, literature, theatre, and cultural performance. He investigates how these cultural practices and articulations grapple with recent developments about sexual and gender minority rights, tourism, the colonial relationships with the Netherlands, and their historical legacy. 

Publications include â€˜Looking for kambrada: sexuality and social anxieties in the Dutch colonial archive, 1882-1923,â€™ Tijdschrift voor genderstudies 22 (2): 125â€“143. This article received an honourable mention for the Gregory Sprague Prize for an outstanding article on LGBT+ and queer history selected by the Committee on LGBT history (2020). Tectum Verlag published his first book, The Question of Dutch Politics as a Matter of Theatre: Theatre and Performance, after the 2008 Financial Crisis in 2017. His other publications focus on LGBT movements in the Netherlands and the former Netherlands Antilles, queer archives, cultural practices and post-colonial intellectuals in the Netherlands.

W.G.S.J.Isenia@uva.nl

summary:
I am a creative, detail-oriented, and independent person. Living, studying, and working in eight different countries worldwide have honed my skills as a high-level researcher, an educator, English language editor, and an (university) administrator. Through teaching and conducting research in the field of archaeology (specializing in archaeobotany, ancient agriculture and food studies) and in teaching English as a second language (certified TEFL/TESOL), I have become a good critical thinker, problem solver, and project planner. I have planned and coordinated large projects and detailed lesson plans, consisting of large international teams and students respectively from up to 10 countries in a single classroom. Furthermore, I am a strong team player in any work environment.  

I am a dual citizen (American and Dutch), and I have developed my Dutch language skills and have a good working proficiency.  I have worked on several editing projects from masters and PhD dissertations, monographs, book chapters, grant proposals, articles, book reviews, annuals reports, recommendation letters, and all content management and editing of websites for former employers including the Groningen Institute of Archaeology (which uses a CMS) and Meade Laboratory at Northwestern University (Evanston, IL, USA). Since 2012, I have been the English Editor for the archaeological journal Tijdschrift voor Mediterrane Archeologie. I have also taught English at the University of Groningen Language Centre. I am a founding member of the Brussels Institute for Advanced Studies (BrIAS); I have helped build its administrative structure and social media presence (with 900+ followers on LinkedIn) and coordinated several international hybrid-format workshops, lectures, fora, and other events for the programâ€™s pilot phase under the theme â€œThe past, present, and future of food, climate, and sustainability.â€

My current research interests are agricultural economies, archaeobotany (the study of human-plant relationships in the past), crop selection, ethnographic studies of traditional food practices, and food security of both the present day and in the past. My main region of specialisation is the Levant and North Africa, with a particular focus on Jordan, Israel, Egypt and Sudan. I am the senior archaeobotanist on the Tall Hisban, Bayda, Shuqayra al-Gharbiyya, Ghor as-Safi complex (Khirbet as-Sheikh Isa, Tawahin as-Sukkar, Umm Tawabin), Khirbet Safra and al-Jumaiyil excavations in Jordan and Khirbet Beit Mazmil excavations in Israel. I am also an archaeobotanist on the EoS-funded AGROS project.

summary:
A free-spirited social entrepreneur with extensive consulting experience in international settings. Passionate about solving social and environmental justice, I have worked with private, public, and grassroots organizations to deliver inclusive and equitable solutions to workplace and community challenges. Providing vision, strategy, and guidance on best practices for DEI, my mission is to build sustainably inclusive companies where people from all different backgrounds and experiences can thrive and contribute to their fullest potential to the success of their company and society. I am driven by curiosity, and my lifelong learning attitude informs how I engage with others in shifting mindsets, building skillsets and relationships that lead to inclusive structures and processes in the workplace. Results-oriented, I do not shy to challenge the status quo, and I motivate teams by taking an evidence-based approach to DEI initiatives. 
My DEI journey starts not with my professional background but with who I am. Shaped by my mixed cultural background, I understand how identities shape us and how the sense of belonging is key to excelling in our professional and personal life. My own journey led me to start "Inclusive Growth," a women-led consultancy business focused on providing solutions to DEI challenges in the workplace. Having lived and worked across Asia, EMEA, Africa, and North America over the past 10+ years has helped me reinforce a context-driven as well as global and local perspective on DEI topics.  
The world is increasingly interconnected, and environmental and social injustices have exposed how much we need a global citizenship mindset to solve for an unpredictable future.  So we need to leverage diversity and tap into a diverse talent pool to innovate and ensure businesses that are relevant today are still relevant tomorrow.  Therefore, DEI work is no luxury but a necessity. The field has much to offer on leadership skills crucial to leading a super diverse workforce.  It offers new perspectives and insights on improving processes, systems, and policies that support the bottom line for organizations. In making a difference, I feel privileged to gain opportunities to work with brave organizations that want to embrace and advocate for DEI within their workplace and communities. 
I offer expertise under Inclusive Growth consultancy on: 
-	Organizational DEI gap assessments
-	DEI strategy
-	Inclusive program and project management
-	Training on DEI topics (anti-racism, bias, inclusive leadership)
-	Coaching 
-	Tailored DEI curriculums
-	Research

Currently a Financial Trainee at the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs, I have a passion for international politics. My passion for  international politics has grown from a desire to understand the world at large. How can civil war struck countries build sustainable peace? How does the growing power of Asian countries influence international politics? Those questions fascinate me, and I aspire to devote my career to answering some of those questions by working on a more secure, peaceful and prosperous world. My passion for international politics has led me to many places: From my masters in International Relations and International Security in Amsterdam and my masters in China & Globalisation at King's College London, to short term study programs in Beijing, Shanghai and Tokyo, to Model United Nations conferences in Oxford and Boston. By studying, engaging in extracurricular activities and reading I aim to develop myself and increase my knowledge of international politics. 

But I also want to help others to develop themselves. I for example commit to high quality, accessible education by having various roles in student government at different universities, I developed and taught the course United Nations and Multilateral Diplomacy (10 EC) at the Radboud University and as Vice President/Secretary of study association Extensus helped connecting 500 honours students throughout Amsterdam. In various board and committee roles I aim to bring people together to connect with one another and to become aware of important global issues. 

I am driven, ambitious and goal oriented, I am both a team player and a good public speaker as well as analytical and a thinker. I like to read and I like to write, but above all I like to be challenged, to grow as a person while helping to make the world a bit more fair and a bit more safe. 

I am always looking for new challenges to develop myself and to contribute to the communities that I am part of. Please feel free to reach out to me if you have any questions to me, or if you feel like we can help each other out.

name: Nelly Samosir
summary:
I am PhD Candidate of Institute of Public Administration, Den Haag, Leiden University and my research focus on public sector reform and perception of public corruption in the post-Soeharto era.
 Indonesia has undergone major transformation in the post-Soeharto period since 1998. A wide array of public sector reform measures have been developed and implemented to make local and/or central government levels more transparent, accountable, and effective. One of the goals has been and still is to ensure that corruption in Indonesia is eradicated as much as possible. Corruption is a serious problem that hinders economic growth and sustainability, and leads to decreasing trust in government and the rule of law. This study examines the relationship between the effect of public sector reform on the prevention and/or eradication of corruption in the Indonesian public sector. For this, public sector reform types and trajectories and theories on corruption will serve as a theoretical framework to find mechanisms potentially underlying such dynamics. In addition, this study takes into account how public sector reform can be aligned with (local) social political and administrative culture and public morality (including perceptions of public integrity) in order to prevent corruption in Indonesian public institutions. The research question of this project will be answered by focusing on an in-depth case study of public sector reform and corruption in West Kalimantan province. In many ways, this province is an interesting and telling case for Indonesia as a whole as well as similar regions across the globe. The paper for this conference will present this research plan, its question and possible theoretical and methodological approaches in more detail.

BIO:
Julia van Mourik is a curator and editor. As director of The One Minutes Foundation, she leads the platform for experimental video art that works closely with various arts education institutions in the Netherlands and internationally. And as director of Lost & Found, she leads the artist salons: an eclectic mix of visual art, video, performance, outsider art, amateur art, music, literature, design, science and more.
She is a member of the Supervisory Board of CREA, member of the Advisory Committee Multi-Year Policy Plan for Art and Culture The Hague 2025-2028, chair of the Advisory Committee on Project Subsidies for Culture of the city of Utrecht and advisor to Amsterdam Fund for the Arts.

Before that she was, among other things, financial director of Top Publishers, which publishes the magazines Fantastic Man and The Gentle Woman, and executive editor of Re-Magazine. She held advisory and board positions for, among others, the Amsterdam Art Council, China Central Academy of Fine Arts, city of Amsterdam, Netherlands Architecture Fund, Netherlands Film Fund and ReykjavÃ­k International Film Festival.
Julia van Mourik studied Publicity and Culture in Amsterdam and did residencies at Raid Projects Gallery in Los Angeles and Townhouse Gallery in Cairo.

summary:
Wigbertson Julian Isenia originates from the Island of Curacao and has an MA degree in Arts and Culture (University of Amsterdam) and two bachelorâ€™s, in interdisciplinary social sciences (University of Utrecht) and Theatre Studies (University of Amsterdam). During his MA, he received a scholarship from the Bekker-la Bastide fund, and the University of Amsterdam nominated him for the ECHO awards. In 2016 he conducted preliminary fieldwork research on same-sex lives and cultures on the island of CuraÃ§ao funded by the Sylva W. de Groot Fund and Stichting Fundatie van de Vrijvrouwe van Renswoude. 

He did his PhD at the University of Amsterdam on a Dutch national research council funded (NWO) research project. His PhD centres on the concept of sexual citizenship beyond their legal conceptualisation in CuraÃ§ao and Bonaire by analysing cultural articulations and practices such as archival collections, literature, theatre, and cultural performance. He investigates how these cultural practices and articulations grapple with recent developments about sexual and gender minority rights, tourism, the colonial relationships with the Netherlands, and their historical legacy. 

Publications include â€˜Looking for kambrada: sexuality and social anxieties in the Dutch colonial archive, 1882-1923,â€™ Tijdschrift voor genderstudies 22 (2): 125â€“143. This article received an honourable mention for the Gregory Sprague Prize for an outstanding article on LGBT+ and queer history selected by the Committee on LGBT history (2020). Tectum Verlag published his first book, The Question of Dutch Politics as a Matter of Theatre: Theatre and Performance, after the 2008 Financial Crisis in 2017. His other publications focus on LGBT movements in the Netherlands and the former Netherlands Antilles, queer archives, cultural practices and post-colonial intellectuals in the Netherlands.

W.G.S.J.Isenia@uva.nl

summary:
I am a creative, detail-oriented, and independent person. Living, studying, and working in eight different countries worldwide have honed my skills as a high-level researcher, an educator, English language editor, and an (university) administrator. Through teaching and conducting research in the field of archaeology (specializing in archaeobotany, ancient agriculture and food studies) and in teaching English as a second language (certified TEFL/TESOL), I have become a good critical thinker, problem solver, and project planner. I have planned and coordinated large projects and detailed lesson plans, consisting of large international teams and students respectively from up to 10 countries in a single classroom. Furthermore, I am a strong team player in any work environment.  

I am a dual citizen (American and Dutch), and I have developed my Dutch language skills and have a good working proficiency.  I have worked on several editing projects from masters and PhD dissertations, monographs, book chapters, grant proposals, articles, book reviews, annuals reports, recommendation letters, and all content management and editing of websites for former employers including the Groningen Institute of Archaeology (which uses a CMS) and Meade Laboratory at Northwestern University (Evanston, IL, USA). Since 2012, I have been the English Editor for the archaeological journal Tijdschrift voor Mediterrane Archeologie. I have also taught English at the University of Groningen Language Centre. I am a founding member of the Brussels Institute for Advanced Studies (BrIAS); I have helped build its administrative structure and social media presence (with 900+ followers on LinkedIn) and coordinated several international hybrid-format workshops, lectures, fora, and other events for the programâ€™s pilot phase under the theme â€œThe past, present, and future of food, climate, and sustainability.â€

My current research interests are agricultural economies, archaeobotany (the study of human-plant relationships in the past), crop selection, ethnographic studies of traditional food practices, and food security of both the present day and in the past. My main region of specialisation is the Levant and North Africa, with a particular focus on Jordan, Israel, Egypt and Sudan. I am the senior archaeobotanist on the Tall Hisban, Bayda, Shuqayra al-Gharbiyya, Ghor as-Safi complex (Khirbet as-Sheikh Isa, Tawahin as-Sukkar, Umm Tawabin), Khirbet Safra and al-Jumaiyil excavations in Jordan and Khirbet Beit Mazmil excavations in Israel. I am also an archaeobotanist on the EoS-funded AGROS project.

summary:
Doctor of Philosophy (dr.) | University Lecturer in Ancient Greek | Teacher in Ancient Greek and Latin Language and Culture

My current research focuses on questions related to the (cultural) identity of the Judean community on Elephantine Island. Further research interests of mine relate to cross-cultural interaction during the first millennium B.C.E, Ancient Near Eastern and Egyptian (matrimonial) law, Aramaic, Demotic and Greek papyrology and linguistics related to the Semitic languages. 

By participating in various public social activities, I attempt to demonstrate that questions related to cultural diversity in antiquity are still relevant to discussions on diversity in modern societies.

Ik ben een serieuze en bevlogen student Griekse en Latijnse taal en cultuur (BA) en rechtsgeleerdheid (LLB) aan de Universiteit van Amsterdam (UvA).

Mijn werkstijl is analytisch en oplossingsgericht; ik bijt me graag vast in lastige vraagstukken en stop niet totdat ik een passende en creatieve oplossing gevonden heb. Met mijn open blik neem ik het infinitief, ben ik zeer toegankelijk en ontvang ik feedback van anderen.

Ik houd erg van lezen â€“ vooral literatuur en poÃ«zie, maar ook politieke en filosofische essays â€“ het bezoeken van toneelvoorstellingen en kunstmusea. Ook ben ik een groot liefhebber van klassieke muziek, opera en wijn. 

Nieuwsgierig als ik ben, volg ik de actualiteiten op de voet en vind ik het boeiend een mening te vormen, zonder vervolgens standvastig in die mening te blijven hangen: een open houding met de mogelijkheid van mening en visie te veranderen ligt dan ook in mijn aard. 

Daarnaast ben ik zeer maatschappelijk betrokken en lid van D66. De behoefte om verantwoordelijkheid te nemen en me in te zetten voor mijn omgeving voelt vanzelfsprekend; waar het kan draag ik mijn steentje bij.

Mijn onderzoek naar culturele en maatschappelijke ontwikkelingen in het Romeinse Rijk tijdens de overgang naar een christelijke samenleving heeft me niet alleen inzicht opgeleverd in het onderwerp zelf, maar ook kennis die kan worden toegepast op andere gebieden en tijdperken, in heden en verleden.
